HEADLINE: Digital Dealmakers Meet in the Middle 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

 BODY:
PICTURE two people haggling over a debt -- say, $1,000 -- that is due in a month. The lender wants the money, but the debtor wants to cut a deal.
 "I'll get you the money in two weeks," the debtor says, "but only if I can pay $800." 
 The lender doesn't give in so easily. "Pay me now," he counters, "and I want $950." On it goes until an agreement is reached or both sides give up. 
 The two sides could be facing off at an office conference table or in a movie about small-time criminals. But in fact just such a scenario plays out regularly online, in the form of negotiations over claims between doctors and insurers, who have enlisted computers to represent them. 
 Software developed by a company called SplitTheDifference makes proposals on behalf of insurers, relying on algorithms to gauge what discount a doctor might accept in exchange for a faster payment.
 The software, which has been used in 20,000 negotiations over the past 18 months, is just one of the ways in which computers are playing a larger role in a growing variety of everyday transactions. The innovations are rooted in advances in mathematics that enable computers to mimic human behavior and in some cases replace them altogether. 
 Most uses of automated negotiations have so far been simple: settling insurance claims, selling excess telecommunications capacity and so on. But the scope for such negotiations is vast. Negotiation software may one day be used to help settle credit card bills, car loans and other financial exchanges, for example. 
 The electronics company Fujitsu is in the early stages of commercializing software that could enable consumers to negotiate deals for air travel, cellphone service or other products.
 Human beings, of course, continue to set the parameters. But computers, which have the capacity to consider millions of offers and counteroffers in seconds, hold out the possibility of crossing the subtlety of the human intellect with the raw power of the processor.
 "The big difference between humans and machines is that humans are really smart but slow, while machines are stupid but fast," said Steve White, a senior manager in the I.B.M. autonomic computing group. "Machines don't make mistakes, either."
 There is an emotional component to negotiation that goes beyond numbers, and computers cannot fully account for it. "What happens in negotiations is, both sides have their own interests so we never both get what we want," Mr. White said. "So what we are concentrating on is getting computers to talk to each other."
 Software advances have extended the automated negotiators' potential scope. Instead of considering price alone, computers can weigh the relative merits of variables including quantity, delivery time and technical specifications. Computers have moved beyond merely matching bids with offers or arbitrating between adversaries; they now can incorporate into the negotiations factors that people may not have considered.
 The trick to making automated negotiation software work is finding a niche where the humans involved will not feel either that the computer is fleecing them or giving too much away to the other side. To be effective, the software must give both sides some control over the process. 
 In practice, that has meant finding industries or business practices that are already digitized and have a high volume of data traffic, like financial markets and telecommunications providers. But while I.B.M. and other developers have had some success creating negotiation software for such areas, most companies are still a long way from being ready for digital dealing because the bulk of their data is on paper or in human memory, not on hard disks. Aside from the money and time needed to digitize such information, managers tend to be wary about ceding job functions or decision-making authority to a machine, a hurdle that must be overcome before negotiation software can achieve broader acceptance.
 "There was a huge amount of belief in automated negotiations, but it has turned into a long slog," said Robert E. Hall, a professor of economics at Stanford University and the author of "Digital Dealing: How E-Markets Are Transforming the Economy" (Norton, 2002). "We're still living in a fax world." 
 That said, companies are having some success selling the software, particularly to manufacturers. Ariba, a software company that is a leader in the field, has created a negotiating tool that gathers information about a company's inventory, production schedules and prices, among other things, and uses the information to field inquiries from potential buyers of its products. Bidders who use the software can specify their tolerance for such variables as return rates, reliability and other factors, which are assigned numerical rankings. By blending quantitative and qualitative information, the software enables users to determine the total cost of a purchase before negotiations begin.
 "Defining the parameters of the negotiations are as important as the negotiations," said Steve Markle, a product manager for Ariba's Spend Management Solution group.
 But to use such a full-service approach, companies must purchase an array of software that may exceed their needs if they are seeking only to automate one or two functions rather than an entire supply chain. 
 SplitTheDifference, focusing more narrowly, found an opportunity to help insurers and doctors haggle over payments that are too small to be handled economically by conventional methods. Ordinarily, insurance companies have 45 days after processing a claim to send the payment to the doctor. The doctors want to get the money sooner, while insurers have an incentive to pay out less money.
 SplitTheDifference's software adjusts itself as the negotiations proceed. The company has found that most doctors reject the first offer and come back with a counteroffer. The software then formulates a new offer that takes into account shifts in the doctor's position reflected by the counteroffer. The process continues until a deal is sealed or the doctor has rejected three proposals, in which case the insurer pays the full claim under the original time frame. The average negotiated settlement reached using the software has been $2,000, and the settlements saved the insurers an average of $400, or 20 percent. SplitTheDifference gets 20 percent of any money the insurer saves as a result of the negotiations.
 Roy Ophir, the company's president, said that insurers and doctors have agreed to automate their negotiations because it is cheaper than the existing arrangement, in whichoutside negotiators working for insurance companies employ telephone operators to call doctors, who are often too busy to talk. Because the fees earned by the outside negotiators are related to the ultimate payments, most of the negotiation companies focus only on claims for substantially more than $2,000.
 The software can be used effectively only if the doctors see an advantage in cooperating. "Financial instruments like insurance payments are where the value proposition is high enough to make negotiation software worthwhile," Mr. Ophir said. "The key is that both sides have to agree."
 Other behavioral patterns have emerged from SplitTheDifference's business. Just 2 percent of the insurers' offers are accepted immediately because doctors routinely think they can get a better result without giving anything away in return. Three-quarters of the negotiations, however, end after the second offer, suggesting that most doctors would rather reach an agreement quickly than haggle endlessly.
 The doctors' behavior does expose a fundamental weakness in the concept underlying algorithm-based negotiation software. Most negotiators have little incentive to divulge initially the outcome they are willing to accept. Participants regularly plead poverty or inflate the value of their goods to get what they want. Such strategic posturing makes it impossible for a computer to determine an "ideal" price and at times can scuttle the negotiations altogether.
 "The right solution depends on the right information, but it's mathematically impossible to come up with an equation to make me truthfully disclose my incentives," said Peter Cramton, an economics professor at the University of Maryland who teaches game theory. "Life would be pretty simple and maybe boring if we just ran into each other and exchanged information honestly. But life is not that simple."
 Dave Marvit and a team of researchers at Fujitsu Laboratories of America, however, have not let that stand in their way. His team, called Project A within Fujitsu, has worked for two years on a software program that can run through millions of potential scenarios in seconds. Unlike "matching" software, which aims to bring together parties with similar preferences, Fujitsu's program tries to narrow differences between groups that initially disagree.
 "We can run millions of prices and have 1,000 or more negotiations that ask how about this, how about that," said Mr. Marvit, whose background is in neuroscience. "Humans look for all these clues to psych out our opponents. Now, you can figure that out by making enough offers back and forth."
 As it moves to make the software commercially available, Fujitsu is hoping it will appeal to companies that swap foodstuffs, computer chips and other commodities. But it could in theory be used to negotiate to get a better rate on a hotel room or cheaper cellphone service as well. In a hypothetical example offered by Mr. Marvit, a traveler might bargain with an airline, offering a mixture of money, frequent-flier mileage and flexibility over route and destinations in exchange for a lower fare on the ticket and other benefits.
 In such a case, the traveler would presumably negotiate with the computer by entering preferences in an online form. The would-be traveler could choose to use software to negotiate on his behalf as well, raising the possibility of a computer-to-computer confrontation. The theory suggests that a stalemate is unlikely even in a computer face-off, however, because the automated negotiators' power to search for potential solutions is so much greater than humans'. 
 The Fujitsu software is relatively simple to use. Negotiators select preferences for categories like quantity, delivery time, shipping and handling costs, unit prices and reliability. Buyers can specify one priority, like the lowest price, or they can negotiate over several terms at once. They might continue asking for 1 percent discounts and tell the computer to stop when the price stops falling.
 Although the software may run thousands of iterations during a negotiation, the last round does not always yield the best price. In fact, in tests of the software, the optimum outcome is often found about halfway through the process. During the remaining repetitions, the price changed little but both sides gave ground on nonprice considerations like earlier or later delivery dates.
 The writing of the program, which Mr. Marvit compares to a computerized chess game, got tricky when colleagues from Japan joined in. Because practices vary by country, there were time-consuming debates about the most effective ways to run a business. As a result, it became clear that negotiating software must be capable of accounting for differences between, say, one business culture's tendency to tolerate defects if the price is right and another's assumption that prompt delivery is a given.
 Despite those differences, Mr. Marvit predicts that the relative ease and low cost of running the software will prompt more participants to trade online. In seconds, they will be able to calculate the cost of choosing blue over red or any number of other variables. Potential business partners could even haggle with each other to decide whether they want to cooperate. This could relieve anxiety that one side was bound to get cheated.
 "Good negotiators know you can do better if you add more business terms to the discussions," Mr. Marvit said. "Not just price, but time and others. The computers can handle more parameters so more value can be squeezed out of the transaction. It's the opposite of a zero-sum game."

HEADLINE: Costs Mount for Yale and Union as Strike Drags On 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
With the strike at Yale University entering its third week and no end in sight, the showdown is starting to exact sizable costs on both the university and the unionized workers.
 Indeed, if the strike drags on much longer, some labor experts say, whatever the ultimate settlement includes will not compensate either side for the losses suffered during the walkout. 
 For Yale officials, the strike has been a public relations quagmire and has set back the university's efforts to repair its history of lamentable town-gown relations. For the 2,000 striking clerical, dining hall and maintenance workers, the walkout has meant two weeks of missed paychecks, fears of many more such weeks and worries about not being able to pay rent and utility bills. 
A third group is also being hurt by the strike -- Yale's students -- even though they are supposedly mere bystanders. Many students complain that the atmosphere on campus has turned bitter, that most dining halls are closed and that they sometimes find it hard to concentrate in class when union bullhorns are bellowing outside.
"The strike is disruptive to the atmosphere here, and it's causing a pretty big rift on campus," said Taylor Chapman, an English major from Houston.
As often happens during strikes, each side is warning the other that to prevent even steeper costs, it would be wise to settle soon by making major concessions. 
Union officials and their community allies warn that every additional day the strike lasts will further undermine an earnest decade-long effort by Yale's president, Richard C. Levin, to mend relations with working-class New Haven. These officials note that several large demonstrations have attacked Yale and that local clergy members and politicians have criticized Yale's behavior in the dispute.
"The hallmark of President Levin's tenure has been to improve town-gown relations, and all that is going up in smoke," said John W. Wilhelm, president of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, the parent of the two union locals on strike. "When Yale puts workers in this polarized position, the cost to Yale, short term and long term, in its stature in the community is extraordinary. Since there are no issues of principle at stake for the university, it seems like an absurd price to pay."
But Dr. Levin insisted that the strike had not done major damage to campus life or town-gown relations.
"Our relations with most of the neighborhood leaders and community groups have remained very strong throughout this," he said, asserting that whatever frictions have developed resulted from union efforts to turn New Haven groups against Yale.
"It took some period of months after the 1996 strike to rebuild and strengthen some of the connections to the community that had been severed," Dr. Levin added. "I'm quite confident we can do that again."
Union leaders do not try to hide that the walkout is squeezing union members. "The cost for the workers is enormous," Mr. Wilhelm said.
The union is paying $250 a week in strike benefits, and has promised strikers help with rent if they face eviction. Nonetheless, many workers are worried about the economic strains of a strike. According to Yale's payroll figures, two-thirds of the 2,900 unionized clerical workers are reporting to work.
The union insists that more than half of the clerical workers are on strike, along with more than 90 percent of the dining hall and maintenance workers.
Laurene, a unionized financial analyst who earns about $27,000 a year and insisted that her last name not be used, said she crossed the picket line because "I couldn't go without pay."
Noting that many workers live paycheck to paycheck, she said the union could never recoup what the workers lose during the strike. "Once you've lost that week of pay, you never catch up," she said.
Mr. Wilhelm, a 1967 Yale graduate, asserted that the strikers would more than regain what they lose during the strike.
"People don't make a short-term mathematical calculation about going on strike," he said. "When we achieve fair pensions and fair salaries and a reasonable measure of job security, the workers will conclude, as in past struggles, that these struggles, while unwelcome, are necessary." 
The dispute appears to be turning into a test of wills, rather than mere haggling over dollars and cents. 
Union officials argue that Yale can settle the dispute at minimum cost. They say that meeting the union's pay demands would cost at most $2 million a year above Yale's offer. They say that meeting the union's demands to increase pensions by more than 50 percent would not require great pension contributions for at least six years because the pension fund is so overfinanced.
But Yale officials insist that meeting the union's demands would cost millions of dollars beyond what the university says is already a generous offer, calling for raises averaging more than 4 percent a year for the clerical workers.
Dr. Levin said recent changes in accounting assumptions resulting from lower interest rates had made the $200 million in pension overfinancing disappear. As a result, he said, any additional pension increases beyond what he said was a 20 percent increase offered by Yale would force Yale to increase its pension contributions.
Union negotiators say one obstacle to a settlement is that Dr. Levin may face criticism from board members and donors if he is perceived as giving too much or giving in to the union. Dr. Levin said he faced no such pressure, saying the university's offer was so generous that, unlike many employers, Yale has not demanded any givebacks.
As for whether the walkout would have lasting negative effects, James Yin, a freshman from Greenwich, Conn., said, "There have been many other strikes at Yale, and they didn't do much damage to Yale's reputation, so one more won't hurt so much."

HEADLINE: Gas Project In Peru Gets Crucial Loan 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
An ambitious project to develop Peru's natural gas fields, sharply criticized by environmental advocates, received a significant endorsement today when the Inter-American Development Bank approved a $75 million loan, bank officials in Washington said.
 The loan opens the door to another $60 million in financing that will help an alliance of companies, including the Hunt Oil Company of Texas, a company with close ties to the Bush administration, to complete one of Latin America's largest energy development projects. 
 Development of the gas fields, called the Camisea project, is led by the Argentine company Pluspetrol. Developers have already spent $1.1 billion to build gas fields on the edge of the Amazon, build two pipelines over the Andes and embark on construction of a gas-processing plant just north of the Paracas marine reserve on Peru's coast. 
In approving the loan, bank officials cited the project's importance to Peru's development, saying it would lower the cost of energy, reduce pollution in the capital (which would receive the natural gas tapped) and make the Andean country an energy exporter. The project, the bank said, could add a 0.8 percentage point growth to Peru's economy each year of its 30-year life.
"At first we had doubts," Enrique V. Iglesias, the president of the Inter-American Development Bank, said in a statement. "But we later thought our responsibility was to support it and assume the risks because we were certain that this is one of the most important projects in the history of Peru."
Developers said the $135 million in loans were not essential to completing the project, which would eventually provide gas liquids and natural gas to the United States. But the loan has a great symbolic value because Peru's government, which supports the project, considers it a seal of approval.
"This means that, most definitely, the I.D.B. assessment team took to their board a proposal that met with all the requirements," Alejandro Segret, the general manager of TGP, an Argentine company constructing the pipeline, said by phone from Lima, Peru's capital. "We are going to continue working the way we were, complying with environmental norms."
The first phase of the Camisea project, valued at $1.6 billion, has been dogged by environmental concerns raised by both ecologists and some United States government officials, who say the development endangers the rain forest, native indigenous communities and the Paracas reserve.
The Inter-American Development Bank's 14-member board, which represents 46 countries, had already delayed a vote on the loan twice. And today's vote did not come without a setback for the developers of Camisea.
The American representative, Jose Fourquet, abstained largely because of concern over the adequacy of an environmental evaluation of the project, people with knowledge of the vote said. On Aug. 28, the Export-Import Bank, a United States government credit agency that had also raised concerns, rejected a $214 million loan.
Officials at the Inter-American Development Bank said the loan was approved after Camisea's developers agreed to give the bank broader powers to monitor environmental issues over the entire length of the project. This is significant because the bank's loan is for the pipeline construction, not for development of the gas fields or of two gas-processing plants.
Bank officials were also swayed by President Alejandro Toledo's proposal, made on Monday, to create a commission to oversee the protection and cleanup of the coastal waters off Paracas where a fractionation plant to separate gas liquids is being built, and where fishmeal plants have been fouling the waters. The energy companies developing Camisea will spend $23.8 million on the bay-protection plan, the Peruvian government said.
Environmental groups, however, said the steps being taken were half-hearted. They charged that the Inter-American Development Bank had caved in to pressure and failed to uphold environmental standards before issuing a large multilateral loan.
"The I.D.B. just committed American taxpayers' money to a project that threatens the natural and cultural environment in Peru," said Aaron Goldzimer, who has closely tracked the Camisea project for Environmental Defense, a environmental group based in New York.
Kathryn S. Fuller, president of the World Wildlife Fund in Washington, said that rejection of the loan would have forced the project to "fix the plan's serious ecological flaws."
Ms. Fuller said that, instead, the bank had "wrapped the plan in a cloak of vague promises, ignored the serious risks and declared it worthy of taxpayer funding." 
The new loans mean that the project will probably move on to its next phase, the construction of a $2 billion plant to liquefy natural gas. By 2007, that facility, under development by Hunt Oil, will provide the United States with an important source of natural gas.

HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Grows at 3.9% Pace 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
Japan's economy expanded 3.9 percent at an annualized pace in the April-to-June quarter -- nearly twice as fast as originally reported -- as capital spending was better than expected.
 The new figures put to rest any lingering concerns that Japan, the world's second-largest economy, would slip back into recession, at least during this year. In fact, Japan's economy is now growing faster than that of the United States, where growth was 3.1 percent in the second quarter. Companies here are investing more in plants and equipment, a sign they expect sales to continue expanding. 
 As in previous quarters, exports also provided a significant lift. Shipments of cars, electronics and other goods to China and the United States helped offset slower sales at home, and the strong demand from overseas shows little sign of slowing. 
The government also reported that Japan's current account surplus expanded 34.6 percent in July from the period a year ago. The current account balance is the broadest measure of goods and services entering and leaving the country.
The brighter numbers provide a lift to Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's bid to win re-election on Sept. 20 as the president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party; a victory would allow him to remain prime minister. The accelerating growth gives him ammunition against rivals who say that he has damaged the economy by cutting public works projects and trying to overhaul the country's vast bureaucracy.
With the economy on the mend, investors are likely to continue moving into Japanese stocks. Though the benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.6 percent to 10,856 today, it hit a 14-month high this week and is widely forecast to rise another 11 percent to 12,000 by the end of the year.
Rising share prices and the expanding economy are taking the heat off the country's banks. The banks hold trillions of yen in stock which they count as capital, so higher share prices allow them to book extra paper profits. Declining bankruptcies and strong corporate profits also produce fewer new nonperforming loans.
Though fears of another financial crisis are fading for now, the government's chief spokesman, Yasuo Fukuda, said, "we should not be complacent" about forcing the nation's banks to write off the estimated 45 trillion yen ($384 billion) in nonperforming loans on their books.
Still, Mr. Fukuda said the economy was "heading in the right direction," a trend that analysts and investors say is hard to deny. The expansion between April and June was the fastest since the fourth quarter of 2000. Capital spending, which makes upabout 15 percent of the economy, grew 4.7 percent last quarter instead of 1.3 percent, as originally reported.
The growth figures in real terms, which account for changes in prices, were also magnified by a deepening of deflation. Prices fell 2.5 percent during the quarter, more than the 2.1 percent initially announced.
While today's report was largely upbeat, growth in the current quarter will probably be more subdued. Unusually cool summer weather led consumers to cut spending on food, travel, clothing and air-conditioners, forcing some companies to scale back their profit forecasts. The weather and the growing economy have increased prices for some produce, and those increases are being passed along to consumers.
Homeowners must also grapple with higher interest rates. The long-term prime rate, which banks use to determine the price of home loans, was raised 0.35 percentage point, to 1.85 percent, this week.
Fires in the last week at factories run by Nippon Steel and Bridgestone have also hampered production at the country's automakers.
More broadly, companies are still in the process of closing factories and trimming debt to strengthen their balance sheets. Last week, for instance, Matsushita Electric Industrial said it would close three factories in Japan before next March.
"Japanese companies still have too much capacity and too many debts, and it will take another three years before they are done cutting them," said Mamoru Yamazaki, an economist at Barclays Capital in Tokyo, who said the economy could contract in the July-to-September quarter. "The problem is getting smaller, but it still remains."
Analysts also criticized the government for not doing enough to reinforce the current recovery. Some say the Bank of Japan should more aggressively pump money into the economy until it ignites inflation. Instead, the central bank has moved only incrementally and refused to adopt an inflation target.
The central bank's policy board is unlikely to alter its stance at its next two-day meeting, which begins Thursday.
Other critics say Mr. Koizumi's penchant for cutting budgets is doing more harm than good. Some economists argue that as long as Japan is enduring deflation, the government should spend more to get consumers and companies spending again.
"Unfortunately, Mr. Koizumi understands none of this," said Richard Koo, an economist at the Nomura Research Institute, who wants the government to spend an extra 10 trillion yen ($85 billion) this year to encourage growth.

(Photo by Bloomberg News) Graph: "Bouncing Back"Japan's economy, which had been contracting, now shows signs of strong growth. Graph tracks the change in Japan's economy, quarterly at an annual rate since 2000. (Source by Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Bond Sales, A Lifeblood For Italians, Face Problems 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SYLVERS

DATELINE: MILAN, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
When Barilla, the world's largest pasta maker, refinanced its debt last year, it turned to the bond market. That was no surprise, considering that stocks were in their third year of decline and the Barilla family had always shunned the possibility of an initial stock offering that would sap their jealously guarded control. 
 What was surprising, perhaps, is that Barilla sold bonds without first obtaining a credit rating from Moody's, Standard & Poor's or Fitch. Barilla, based in Parma, Italy, which will have sales this year of about 5 billion euros ($5.61 billion) and has a brand name known the world over, is paying just 4.63 percent interest on the five-year bond, less than 1 percentage point above the rate on a similar Italian government bond sold the same week. 
 Barilla is certainly not alone. Other Italian companies with well-known brand names and unrated bonds outstanding include Bulgari, Benetton, Ducati, Pirelli and Prada. Italian companies are Europe's biggest sellers of unrated bonds and account for half the 20 billion-euro market, whether measured by number of issues, value of issues or number of companies selling the bonds. This is all the more impressive given that Italy's corporate bond market accounts for only about 5 percent of the total in Europe.
Barilla might have just gotten in under the wire, though, for just before its bond sale, another large Italian company defaulted on its debt, essentially closing the spigot for this type of borrowing, at least for now.
In the United States, unrated corporate bonds are harder to sell because many investment funds cannot hold the securities and individual investors have largely steered clear.
Barilla and other companies had several potential reasons for not seeking a credit rating, but chief among them was a desire to sell bonds with a lower rate of interest than would be possible if Moody's Investors Service or one of the other agencies gave them a rating.
"If you know your company would have to pay 8 percent interest on a bond if it got a rating, and you also know that based on your brand-name recognition you can sell the same bond at 6 percent interest if you don't have a rating, what are you going to do?" said Pierluigi Volini, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs in London who covers high-yield bonds and published a report in December on unrated Italian bonds.
The 0.8 of a percentage point that separates the Barilla bond from an Italian government bond is equal to the interest that companies with a mid-range investment-grade credit rating from Moody's or S.&P. have to pay to sell a similar bond on the market. By exploiting its brand-name recognition, Barilla essentially gained an investment-grade rating without having a rating.
Some executives argue that if their companies are going to sell only one or two bonds, it does not make financial sense for them to spend roughly 50,000 euros to get Moody's or S.&P. to rate them. And it can cost as much as 30,000 euros a year on top of that to keep a rating up to date. Getting a rating is certainly in a company's interest if it will lower, even minimally, the interest rate on a bond. Lowering the interest on 300 million euros in bonds, the amount Barilla sold, by half of a percentage point saves 1.5 million euros a year.
Barilla's tapping of the bond market in November came just two weeks after Italy's first-ever corporate bond default. Cirio, Italy's biggest canned-food producer, failed to make an interest payment on an unrated bond that had been sold six months earlier.
The company is now in liquidation and has defaulted on all its 1.1 billion euros in outstanding bonds. Sergio Cragnotti, Cirio's largest shareholder, resigned as chairman in the wake of the default and is under investigation for fraud.
"Once Cirio happened, that changed everything and effectively closed the unrated bond market in Italy," said Stefano Zeni, a credit analyst with Moody's in Milan -- though Barilla was able to complete its sale because the market had not had time to absorb the lessons of the Cirio default.
Corrado Passera, chief executive of Banca Intesa, Italy's largest lender and the lead manager on the Cirio bond sale, said in July that his bank would no longer sell unrated bonds. His comments were echoed by other Italian bank executives.
Even before the Cirio fiasco, unrated bonds were becoming harder to sell in Italy. After market declines that began in March 2000, Italians have increasingly turned to money managers, who are less likely than individual investors to buy unrated bonds based on brand-name recognition. Another factor favoring the move away from unrated bonds, said Mr. Volini of Goldman Sachs, is a general development of Italian capital markets. That has broken the cycle of banks directly financing companies. Since banks do their own credit analysis before lending, ratings were often unnecessary.
Barilla executives declined to be interviewed for this article and a spokesman declined to comment on the company's decision not to get a rating. One person at the company said the decision was based on logistical reasons.
"At the time that the bond was sold, the seven or eight people in the finance department were dealing with other things, and they didn't have time to dedicate to getting a credit rating," the person said. "We have nothing against ratings, and it's clear after what happened with Cirio that we will never be able to return to the market without one."
While the market for new unrated bonds may be all but closed, there are 15 billion euros in the securities coming due by 2007, Mr. Zeni at Moody's said. And should Barilla or one of the other companies with bonds and no rating need to refinance or raise funds for other reasons, this time around they will probably be forced to find time for one of the credit rating agencies.

HEADLINE: For This Old Program, An All-Thumbs Host 

BYLINE:  By HILARY DE VRIES

DATELINE: AGUA DULCE, Calif. 

 BODY:
IF ignorance is bliss, Kevin O'Connor is one happy man. Last year, he was a new homeowner who couldn't figure out how to strip his wallpaper. Next month he joins Norm Abram, Tom Silva and the rest of the "This Old House" team to become their improbable new host.
 Such is the curious fortune of Mr. O'Connor, 35, a freckle-faced banker from Boston whose biggest claim to fame used to be approving loans to sports teams like the Red Sox. That was before he was tapped to replace Steve Thomas, host of "This Old House" for 14 years. 
 "I grew up watching 'This Old House,' but when the producers called me at the bank, I thought they were calling me for a loan," Mr. O'Connor said. 
He spoke while gazing across the sun-blasted Martian landscape that is the front yard of Sherry Steele, a marketing analyst and -- for today's filming purposes -- baffled homeowner with a sprinkler system problem in Agua Dulce, about 40 miles north of Los Angeles.
During the taping session, Mr. O'Connor happily displayed his lack of expertise. Although it was nearly 100 degrees and the air was tangy with the smell of the neighbor's horse barns, he peppered Mrs. Steele with questions about her landscaping problems. 
Mr. O'Connor will not appear on the show until October, when the program begins its 2003-4 season with a new project: the conversion of a historic gambrel-roof barn in Concord, Mass., into an in-law apartment. But he has been on the job for months. Joined by Mr. Silva, the show's contractor, and its landscaper, Roger Cook, he had flown to California from Boston to tape segments based on questions from viewers like Mrs. Steele. 
Mr. O'Connor, who could pass for Mr. Thomas's younger brother, is along for the ride as a learning experience. Or not, as the case may be. 
"My role on the show is to not know anything, but to ask the questions of the guys -- our experts -- who do," Mr. O'Connor said, comparing himself to the average viewer. "I'm not actually supposed to get too smart."
His arrival is only the latest change in a yearlong renovation of the fusty Emmy-winning series "This Old House," after 25 years television's oldest and highest-rated home show despite a wave of cable TV hits like "Trading Spaces" and "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy."
Two years ago, WGBH, the PBS affiliate in Boston that has owned and produced "This Old House" since it began in 1979, sold the program and its trappings -- syndicated reruns, a monthly magazine and Web site, books and videos -- to Time Inc. Although the series will remain on PBS, the new owners quickly set about spit-polishing the purposefully folksy show, expanding it to 60 minutes and giving it a new name -- "The New This Old House Hour" -- while adding a companion series, "Ask This Old House," which invites viewers to quiz the experts. 
As Mr. Thomas, then the series host, said at the time: "Real estate is the one bright spot in the economy, so the whole home renovation enterprise has gotten bigger. Our job is to follow that."
Early this year Mr. Thomas, 50, abruptly stepped down, saying he wanted time to pursue interests like skiing and sailing. A ship captain and amateur carpenter, Mr. Thomas was only the second host in the show's long history. He took the job in 1989 after Bob Vila, a Boston builder and the show's original host, left in an acrimonious dispute with the series over a policy forbidding employees to endorse products. (Mr. Vila went on to create his own syndicated show, "At Home With Bob Vila.") 
"When Steve told us he was leaving, it was quite frightening," said Bruce Irving, a senior producer. "First of all, Steve was really good and secondly, how do you fill a job like that? I mean, we didn't want to be inundated with every guy with a plaid shirt and a pickup."
Eager to avoid a replay of the previous auditions -- the producers had heard from more than 400 would-be Mr. Thomases, from contractors to a concert violinist -- they quietly auditioned several candidates, including architects and a developer. 
"We had a big internal debate about whether we should go with a host in the trade or not in the trade," Mr. Irving said. "We thought we'd look at someone in a related field, like home design or architecture."
Russell Morash, who created the series and remains its director and executive producer, said, "After those initial auditions, I realized what we really wanted was someone who had the curiosity, interest and enthusiasm of a real homeowner."
Mr. O'Connor was a vice president of Fleet Bank in Boston when he surfaced last November. He and his wife, Kathleen, had bought a Victorian house outside Boston, and he had contacted the show with questions about stripping the wallpaper. 
The couple and their conundrum became a segment on "Ask This Old House," where Mr. O'Connor made an impression. His camaraderie with the series regulars became clear during production of the segment when Mr. Silva played a practical joke on him by gluing his tools to the floor.
"Very believable" is the way Mr. Irving characterized the banker who was intent on renovating his own home. "A homeowner with a day job."
Mr. O'Connor started his new job in April and spent two weeks this summer at an ad hoc boot camp,working alongside Mr. Silva and the rest of the staff, but he freely admits he didn't learn all that much. "The reality is, you don't learn anything in two weeks," said Mr. O'Connor, who grew up in New Jersey, the son of an engineer. 
The biggest question for Time Inc. is how viewers will react to the new alter ego. As the least experienced of the three hosts, Mr. O'Connor is handling a franchise that reaches a total of nearly 45 million viewers, magazine readers and Web site visitors, and all are fair game for rival programs.
Kathleen O'Connor conceded that it was "a little bizarre Kevin got the job," adding, "He has a passion for renovating houses, but even his friends didn't believe him when he told them he was the show's new host." 
Stacey Lynn Koerner, a vice president at Initiative, a media services company that evaluates programs for advertisers, said that the stakes for Time Inc. may be high, but that Mr. O'Connor's role is less important than one might think. "People watch these shows because they want the expertise, not because of the host," she said. Indeed, she suggested that Mr. O'Connor's background as a banker with an M.B.A. may make him a wise choice. "A lot of the audience for these home shows are young Wall Street types wanting to fix up their homes," she said, "and Kevin fits that mold."
Mr. O'Connor's new training has already had one positive effect: speeding along his own home renovation. Since joining the series, he and Ms. O'Connor have completed the kitchen remodeling, which included moving a load-bearing wall. "We spent Easter weekend hanging the cabinets," she said with a laugh. "This is Kevin's dream job, and luckily he's already learned a lot."

HEADLINE: Election Race? First, Check Out This Bike 

BYLINE:  By NOAH SHACHTMAN

 BODY:
GEN. WESLEY K. CLARK is a hot topic in the chat rooms and clubhouses of Democratic politics, where pundits and activists are sizing up his possible presidential candidacy. More than $1 million and 13,000 volunteers have been pledged as part of an online movement to draft General Clark, the former NATO supreme commander and CNN military analyst, to enter the 2004 race. 
 But right now, General Clark wants to talk about bicycles. 
 The retired general has been devoting much of his time to running a company making a new kind of electric motor that does not require gears or a transmission, but uses computer algorithms to maximize torque and efficiency. 
 The company, WaveCrest Laboratories of Dulles, Va., hopes to put these motors into hybrid gas-electric cars or even hydrogen-powered fuel-cell cars one day. But for now, WaveCrest is focused on bikes.
 By adding one of its "adaptive motors" to a conventional bicycle frame, WaveCrest claims that its two-wheeler can go Lance Armstrong speed -- 30 miles an hour -- with hardly any pedaling at all. 
 With General Clark in command, WaveCrest is looking to the military market first.
 "The military always needs transportation for its men, but there are lots of places like tight alleys in urban areas where you don't want to be in a Humvee, which is big and noisy," said General Clark, the company's chairman. The electric bike is light and simple, he said. "You turn the handle, and it just scoots. There's no sound. Just acceleration and speed. Just a shoosh on the pavement."
 Infantrymen could ride the souped-up bikes to battle rather than marching, he said. Downed pilots could zip away on an electrified 21-speed bike instead of waiting to be captured.
 Bicycles have been used in the military for more than a hundred years. Six percent of British troops in the Boer War in southern Africa at the turn of the 20th century were on bicycles. Bicycles were common during World War I. 
 In World War II, the Japanese were able to take over the Malaysian Peninsula in 70 days largely because of the speed of its cycle-mounted troops, according to Jim Fitzpatrick, author of "The Bicycle in Wartime" (Bassey's, 1998).
 In the 1960's General Clark witnessed the use of bicycles by the Vietcong to carry supplies down the Ho Chi Minh Trail in the Vietnam War. The Special Forces Command is trying out a half-dozen prototypes of General Clark's folding-frame bikes, which are powered by two 36-volt nickel-metal-hydride batteries and have a range of about 30 miles. Several other Army units and law enforcement agencies, including the police department in General Clark's hometown, Little Rock, Ark., are considering using them as well.
 But some military analysts doubt that the electric bicycles will fit into American war planning.
 "Bicycles have worked because they're simple, light, and could be maltreated," Mr. Fitzpatrick saidt. At 64 pounds, the WaveCrest bikes are far heavier than ordinary models, he said, "so I'm somewhat dubious that they'll work."
 Tim Brown, a senior fellow at the public-policy group GlobalSecurity.org, is not convinced, either. "I'm skeptical that someone like Scott O'Grady would have this in his ejection seat," said Mr. Brown, referring to an American pilot who was shot down over Bosnia in 1995.
 WaveCrest is one of many companies developing advanced electric motors. What makes its motor different is how it is controlled, said Mike Fritz, a WaveCrest engineering executive. Most motors of this kind fire a predetermined sequence of electrical pulses that activate a series of electromagnets. These electromagnets repel and attract a set of standard, or permanent, magnets, making the motor spin. 
 WaveCrest puts six optical sensors in its motor, which inform a customized central processor thousands of times per second how fast the motor is rotating and how much torque it is generating. The chip then uses algorithms to determine precisely what kind of electrical pulses are needed to make the motor run most efficiently at that speed and at that torque. 
 Karl Brauer, editor in chief of www.edmunds.com, an automotive site, said: "With most electric motors, there's a range of speed and torque that they're happiest in, a sweet spot. What WaveCrest is trying to do is have the entire range be a sweet zone, from barely turning to turning rapidly."
 That sweet spot occurs in many electric motors when they are spinning at thousands of revolutions per minute. When used in a vehicle, some kind of transmission or reduction gearing is needed to slow things down so the wheels can turn at their proper rate, said Elias Strangas, an electrical engineering professor at Michigan State University. WaveCrest's design could eliminate the need for a transmission or gears by getting the motor's r.p.m. to match the wheel's needs. Small motors could even be put at the wheels themselves instead of having one large motor under a car's hood. The WaveCrest bicycle relies on such a setup.
 These so called in-hub motors could drastically cut the weight of a hybrid or fuel-cell car, Mr. Brauer said. And that could allow the car to carry extra batteries and extend its range.
 But that is in the uncertain future. As Professor Strangas noted, "Quite a few people have tried to produce similar kinds of motors before and haven't been able to get the economics right."
 For now, WaveCrest's main focus is electric bicycles, which General Clark said were practical to build because of their one-horsepower engines. A consumer version of the WaveCrest is scheduled to go on sale this fall for about $1,500.
 Two scientists, Alexander Pyntikov and Boris Maslov, invented the motor behind the bikes. They moved to the United States from Russia in the 90's, filed a patent on the motor in 1998 and, a year later, connected with a Washington technology entrepreneur, Allen Andersson. The three founded WaveCrest, with Mr. Andersson investing $17 million so far in the company, which now has nearly 100 employees. After informally advising the company for several years, General Clark became its chairman in April.
 Since then, he said, he has been devoting up to a quarter of his time to the company. But he may have to cut back on his WaveCrest responsibilities if he decides to pursue that higher-profile job.

HEADLINE: Bill on Changes in Welfare Advances to Full Senate 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
Welfare legislation cleared a major hurdle today as the Senate Finance Committee approved a bill that would increase work requirements for welfare recipients.
 The bill, approved on a party-line vote of 9 to 8, would also spend $1 billion over the next five years to promote marriage as a goal for people on welfare. 
 The House approved a similar bill in February. Both bills make fundamental changes in the 1996 welfare law, which has prompted millions of poor people to move from welfare to work. Administration officials said President Bush supported both the House bill and the Senate version. 
It is unclear when the full Senate may take up the measure. Major provisions of the 1996 law expire on Sept. 30, but Congress could extend them for a few months, as it has done several times in the last year.
"Getting the bill out of the Senate Finance Committee is a huge step," said Wade F. Horn, assistant secretary of health and human services in charge of welfare policy. "Our very strong preference is for Congress to move the bill quickly in order to provide states with stability and predictability, so they can make long-term plans for their welfare programs."
Democrats and at least one Republican member of the Finance Committee said the bill did not provide enough money for child care.
"We are trying to help families get off welfare," the senior Democrat on the panel, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, said. "But to get off welfare, single mothers need adequate child care."
Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, had previously blocked action on the measure, saying it did not have enough money for child care. But she voted to send it to the Senate floor today after having received a commitment guaranteeing her ability to offer an amendment to provide $5 billion to $6 billion for child care, on top of the $1 billion increase in the bill.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, says nearly half the states have reduced child-care subsidies or restricted eligibility in the last two years.
Ms. Snowe also persuaded the committee to give states the option of letting welfare recipients meet most work requirements by attending college or other postsecondary institutions. Maine has such a program, Parents as Scholars.
Last year, Mr. Bush denounced that provision of the Senate bill, saying it would pay welfare recipients to attend college for five years. But Ms. Snowe said the Maine program had been "an unqualified success," enabling many people to move off welfare to positions that pay more than $11 an hour.
Since the welfare law was signed in 1996, the number of people on welfare has plunged, to 5 million from 12.2 million, a 59 percent decline. Federal officials said they had seen a slight decline even as unemployment rose and the nation struggled through a recession in the last year.
Under current law, recipients are generally required to work 30 hours a week. Mr. Bush wanted to increase that to 40 hours. The House bill would require 38 hours. Under the Senate bill, most recipients would have to work 34 hours.
The Senate bill also provides up to $1.5 billion for programs to help low-income people "form and sustain healthy marriages."
Mr. Baucus said he doubted the value of such programs.
But Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, said: "The evidence is overwhelming. Children raised in married households do much better by every social, economic and educational indicator."
Under current law, at least 50 percent of a state's adult recipients are supposed to be engaged in work or preparing for work. The Senate bill, like the House measure, would gradually increase that figure, to 70 percent in 2008.
By voice vote, the Finance Committee approved a separate bill to improve health insurance coverage for families of children with severe disabilities. Under the bill, thousands of working parents could buy Medicaid coverage for which they would otherwise be ineligible.
"Medicaid is a safety net program, and one must be impoverished to be eligible," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, the chief sponsor of the bill. "This presents a terrible choice for many low- and middle-income families who have a child with special health care needs. They must choose between work or impoverishment. In the worst cases, parents consider the devastating choice of relinquishing custody so the child can obtain services."

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Bush's Speech Offers Focus for Democrats' Attacks

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
In a classic case of unintended consequences, President Bush's major address to the nation on Iraq seems to have emboldened -- rather than muted -- his Democratic critics.
 Democratic presidential candidates have escalated their attacks since the president's speech to the nation on Sunday night, in which he declared Iraq the "central front" in the war on terrorism and asked for an additional $87 billion and more help from the United Nations to handle it. Like their colleagues on Capitol Hill, Democratic candidates are attacking both Mr. Bush's management of postwar Iraq and the huge toll that his spending request will take on the domestic agenda, including education and jobs. 
 Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, in an address to the Council on Foreign Relations today, asserted, "Both abroad and at home, the Bush administration has hoarded authority, bungled diplomacy, pushed allies to the margin and divided rather than multiplied the strength we need to win the war on terror."
Mr. Lieberman, who supported military action in Iraq, said an international administrator should take control of the country within 60 days.
The Democratic candidates are bitterly divided over whether Congress should have authorized Mr. Bush to invade Iraq; that was evident at the debate on Tuesday. Most are careful to say they will do what is necessary to protect American troops, including, if need be, backing the president's financing request. But they are eager to highlight what they consider fundamental miscalculations in Mr. Bush's performance as commander in chief, which has been considered his greatest strength in the campaign.
"President Bush and Karl Rove thought the issue of Iraq would be their greatest asset going into the re-election campaign," Terry McAuliffe, the national Democratic chairman, told reporters today. "It actually could turn into a liability."
Stanley Greenberg, a longtime Democrat pollster, argued: "Democrats can engage in a robust debate on security and foreign policy issues and be more than competitive. There's no need to walk in trepidation behind a president who's a wartime leader."
Republican strategists say they are confident that Mr. Bush will retain his party's traditional advantage on national security, which looms large in the post-9/11 world. Even with Mr. Bush's decline in the polls after major combat ended in Iraq, a Washington Post poll in August found Americans, by two to one, said Republicans would do better handling the war against terrorism.
Moreover, the Republican Party, led by Ed Gillespie, the national party chairman, has begun an aggressive defense against Democratic attacks, describing them as "political hate speech." In an interview today, Mr. Gillespie said, "There is a contrast here -- while President Bush is attacking the terrorists, the Democrats are attacking President Bush."
Mr. Gillespie added that the Democratic candidates, "in their effort to appeal to their hard-core antiwar and anti-President Bush base in their party, are adopting a weak and vacillating foreign policy that will hurt them with their broader electorate."
Some nonpartisan analysts agree that the Democrats face some risk in criticizing the costs of postwar operations. Andy Kohut, the pollster who heads the Pew Research Center, said: "What Bush did pretty well was say: 'This is about terrorism. We're confronting the battle on terrorism in Iraq and over Iraq.' And that's a very good way of framing it for the American public." 
James B. Steinberg, a member of the Clinton administration who is now an analyst at Brookings, said: "At some point, the issue will be joined. Was this necessary for the war on terrorism, and do people feel as a result of having done this that they are safer or less safe in the face of terrorism? How people feel about that question a year from now will be critical."
Still, Democrats seem energized by what many assert was a major admission of error by Mr. Bush -- in not seeking more international support in the action against Iraq, in underestimating the difficulty of postwar reconstruction, in not preparing the American people for such a lengthy operation, in not having a realistic plan.
Moreover, it has enabled many Democrats to link Mr. Bush's expensive policies in Iraq to what they say is his reckless handling of the economy and the federal budget at home.
"We cannot authorize or appropriate $87 billion without pulling back some of the unfair Bush tax cut for the wealthiest Americans and investing in the United States of America," Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said at the debate on Tuesday night. "If we can open firehouses in Baghdad, we can keep them open in the United States of America."
But, many analysts said, the Democrats are walking a difficult line, opposing the president's handling of Iraq, but recognizing that the country cannot "cut and run" and that they may, ultimately, have to give the administration what it needs.
Six of the nine Democratic candidates are in the Senate or the House, and will therefore have to vote on the president's spending request. Most have spelled out various conditions they would seek before casting their vote, declaring they will not vote for an open-ended request or a blank check. But most said they would, in the end, do what it took to protect American troops.
A spokesman for former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, whose surge in the Democratic field was largely powered by his antiwar stance, said he would oppose the spending request unless it was taken out of the administration's tax cuts.
In the end, even as Democrats move toward a more unified message against Mr. Bush on Iraq after the brutal divisions caused by the war, the strains of a competitive primary campaign remain, and may simply re-emerge in different form. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, left, and Howard Dean on Tuesday after a debate. The two have criticized President Bush's handling of Iraq. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: TWO YEARS LATER: THE CONTEXT; 
Counterterror Proposals Are a Hard Sell

BYLINE:  By ERIC LICHTBLAU

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 

 BODY:
President Bush, seeking still greater powers to fight terrorism, appears to have calculated that the renewed memories of the Sept. 11 attacks evoked by their second anniversary will be enough to outweigh rising concerns over civil liberties.
 Mr. Bush's proposal for stronger counterterrorism laws, made in a toughly worded speech today, faces a hard sell in Congress, as the administration tries to persuade skeptical lawmakers in both parties that the authorities will not abuse their growing power to investigate and lock up suspects. 
 The strategy is similar to the one the White House has employed in the fight over its tax cut plan. After its first tax cut in 2001 came under intense attack from Democrats and many economists for raising the deficit, the administration responded this year not by retreating but by successfully championing yet another tax cut. 
But in this case, the administration is reviving some of the same terrorism proposals, including the expanded use of nonjudicial subpoenas in terror cases, that were considered and rejected by Congressional negotiators in debate over the Patriot Act in the fall of 2001.
In the last several months, Attorney General John Ashcroft proposed making more terrorism-related crimes eligible for the death penalty and making it more difficult for suspects to be released on bail, two critical components of the new initiative. But rather than using Mr. Ashcroft, a polarizing figure, to unveil the proposals, the White House decided to have Mr. Bush personally announce the plan on the eve of the second anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks -- and at an early stage of the presidential campaign.
Still, the political climate has changed markedly since the original Patriot Act was passed overwhelmingly by the House and Senate. Some 160 communities around the country have voiced formal objections to the legislation, civil rights groups have sued to have it overturned, and it has become a rallying point for Democratic presidential candidates on the campaign trail who say it smacks of Big Brother tactics.
Iin pushing for new counterterrorism authority, the White House appeared undaunted by the increasing attacks from both Republicans and Democrats over the Patriot Act and the government's expanded powers. 
"The best defense is a good offense, and this administration plays that strategy very well," said Beryl Howell, a specialist in surveillance and counterterrorism law and a former Senate Democratic aide. "Their attitude is, 'if you think the USA Patriot Act is so bad, wait and see what else we want.' They're marking their position."
Administration officials and supporters said they thought the intense focus on the law in recent weeks could actually help their cause. "If you have a lively debate, that's when you have the best chance to persuade the public and the Congress," said Viet Dinh, a former senior aide to Mr. Ashcroft who helped to draft the act.
Democrats in Congress were quick to attack the president's proposals.
Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, said: "Removing judges from providing any check or balance on John Ashcroft's subpoenas does not make us safer, it only makes us less free. Of course terrorists should not be released on bail, but this administration has a shameful record of deeming law-abiding citizens as terrorists and taking away their rights."
Other critics said the plan amounted to a revival of some of the main proposals included in that earlier plan.
"They don't want to call this a sequel to the Patriot Act, but the fact is that that's what it is," said Timothy Edgar, legislative counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union.
Democrats said the administration now appears intent on introducing new counterterrorism proposals in smaller, piecemeal fashion, rather than submitting to Congress an all-encompassing plan that many predict would face near-certain defeat. 
And by having Mr. Bush announce the plan at the F.B.I. Academy in Quantico, Va., a setting clearly identified with law enforcement and on the day before the Sept. 11 anniversary, the White House hopes to quell criticism, especially from Republicans. 
Even Republicans with deep-seated concerns about expanding the government's counterterrorism authority said the timing made it difficult for them to speak out today without appearing insensitive to the memory of those killed on Sept. 11 and disloyal to President Bush.
"This is the president talking and not John Ashcroft," said a Republican Congressional aide, "and the fact is that we have to be as supportive as we can of the president and his efforts to combat terrorism."

HEADLINE: New Accounts Of Meetings At Big Board On Chief's Pay 

BYLINE:  By LANDON THOMAS Jr. and FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Richard A. Grasso decided to give up $48 million in benefits owed to him by the New York Stock Exchange only hours before the decision was announced, and after some members of the board said he should, several directors said yesterday.
 Just days earlier, one director said, Mr. Grasso said he did not want to give up the money because to do so would "repudiate the process" that had determined his compensation over the years he served as the exchange's chairman and chief executive. 
 Documents released by the exchange yesterday also indicated that the board's compensation committee did not learn until late last year that Mr. Grasso's pay was considerably higher than that of executives at financial services companies and that his pension benefits were almost six times the size of theirs. 
The combined picture is of a board that -- while it received and approved Mr. Grasso's contracts with the exchange -- did not understand how the contracts were enriching Mr. Grasso to a far greater degree than any previous Big Board chairman. Several directors said they did not know about the $48 million until the day Mr. Grasso gave up the pay.
Mr. Grasso and the exchange have faced questioning since last month, when the exchange disclosed that he was paid $139.5 million in deferred compensation and pension benefits he had previously earned. Some were shocked that an official whose duties include regulating Wall Street firms would have been granted so much money by a board that included top officials of investment banking firms.
His pay soared under a contract signed in 1999 at the height of the Wall Street boom. It appears that many directors did not understand how generous that contract was.
The picture emerging is of a board far less united in support of Mr. Grasso than has been reported. The documents show that early last month H. Carl McCall, the chairman of the Big Board's compensation committee, told the committee that he believed that some directors would not support the decision to pay out the money to Mr. Grasso. And the reports from directors indicate that Mr. Grasso rejected the money only after some directors said he should. 
In a telephone meeting on Tuesday, several directors said, Mr. Grasso discussed the $48 million and then left the conversation to allow the board to discuss the matter without him. The $48 million was to be disclosed later that day to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which had requested information.
Directors -- including Philip J. Purcell, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley; William B. Harrison Jr., the chief executive of J. P. Morgan Chase; and Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chief executive of Goldman Sachs -- argued that the board should demand that Mr. Grasso forgo these payments, and Mr. McCall agreed, directors said. Some others argued that it was Mr. Grasso's money and that he should be able to make his own decision.
But the debate became moot within minutes when Mr. Grasso rejoined the conversation and, according to one director, said: "I want to move ahead. None of this is good for the exchange." He added: "I didn't ask for this money. I don't spend this money, and I shouldn't accept this money."
A brief silence ensued, the director said, until Mr. Paulson spoke up, saying, "Dick, you are doing the right thing and we all support you." Other directors then joined in voicing their support of the decision.
Mr. Grasso could not be reached for comment last night.
If board members did not know until recent days that Mr. Grasso was entitled to that money, however, they may have failed to study the new contract approved by the board last month. While it does not cite $48 million, it spells out the payments that add up to that sum. That contract was shown to reporters by the exchange yesterday.
The Tuesday meeting was not the first time that director opposition had persuaded Mr. Grasso to consider backing down. Early in August, even as the board was moving to pay him the money he had been seeking for many months, he said action should be delayed, but the board's compensation committee decided to move ahead anyway.
Minutes of the board's Aug. 7 compensation committee meeting quote Mr. McCall as saying: "Some directors were concerned with the timing of the new agreement and asked questions regarding disclosure. Some directors had called Mr. Grasso to express their concerns." 
Mr. McCall, the minutes added, informed the committee that "Mr. Grasso did not think it was wise to proceed at this time."
But the compensation committee rejected that idea. Laurence D. Fink, the chairman and chief executive of BlackRock Inc., an institutional investment firm, was quoted in the minutes as saying he "felt the timing would be no better if the decision were deferred, and the issue should be dealt with immediately."
Several directors, who insisted that they not be identified, said opposition in August came in part from Wall Street executives, who were particularly concerned about public reaction. While they did not dispute the notion that Mr. Grasso should be paid the money that was contractually his, some opposed allowing him to receive such a large payment while he remained chairman. Some said more time was needed to analyze the numbers and try to reach a more palatable solution. This group included Mr. Purcell, Mr. Harrison and Mr. Paulson, according to other directors. Each of these directors, through their spokesmen, declined to discuss the meetings.
They were persuaded to allow the payment to proceed and to be disclosed immediately.
By then, the board appears to have felt trapped. The new agreement with Mr. Grasso, which extended his contract until 2007, was expected to save the exchange several million dollars by changing the way some bonuses and benefits were calculated. The money he was to receive was owed to him, the committee was told.
The contract was approved at the same time the board was working on revising its corporate governance, also under pressure from the S.E.C., a process that seemed likely to lead to disclosures of Mr. Grasso's pay.
At the Aug. 7 committee meeting, according to the minutes, Jurgen E. Schrempp, the chairman of the management board of DaimlerChrysler, "asked whether the present agreement was legally binding" and was assured that it was.
He emphasized that the amount being paid was determined by employment agreements entered into in 1995 and 1999, and "stressed the need for a discussion of Mr. Grasso's further compensation, which still requires a firm decision."
The new contract gives the board substantial discretion to set Mr. Grasso's annual bonus. The size will not be known until next spring.
But Mr. McCall seemed to indicate yesterday that Mr. Grasso might get less in the future. "The important thing is that this is behind us," he said in a statement. "We now have to completely revamp our compensation policies and set new benchmarks for compensation based on today's economic realities."
Mr. Grasso's high compensation was in sharp contrast to that of William H. Donaldson, his predecessor as Big Board chairman. Mr. Donaldson is now the chairman of the S.E.C., which made the inquiry. He was paid $1.5 million a year when he joined the New York Stock Exchange in 1991, and had total compensation of $1.85 million in his best-paid year.
According to documents, Mr. Grasso asked last year to take out the money that had accrued in a variety of plans. The amounts appear to have come as a surprise to some directors, and the compensation committee decided on Sept. 25, 2002, that a new consultant, with no ties to the exchange, should review his compensation.
Kenneth Langone, the founder of Home Depot and the chairman of Invemed Associates, a brokerage firm, was then the head of the board's compensation committee. He chose Robert J. Stucker and Thomas P. Desmond of Vedder, Price, Kaufman & Kammholz, a Chicago law firm. 
The new consultant looked at the pay of 16 chief executives of financial services companies. At the Oct. 6 compensation committee meeting, Vedder Price provided charts showing that in that group the median compensation -- including salary, bonus and equity-related grants like options -- was $13.46 million in 2001, and that someone would rank in the top quartile of that group if paid $18.23 million. Mr. Grasso, it said, received $31.25 million. (The figure is $700,000 higher than the one released by the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday. Officials could not explain the discrepancy when asked yesterday.)
The Vedder Price lawyers also reported that it was unusual for companies to include long-term incentive compensation in calculating pension benefits, as the Big Board did. The result was that Mr. Grasso, who is now 57, would be owed at least $122 million if he retired at 60 and took a lump-sum pension distribution. The comparable figure for the medium financial services firm was $21 million, and $29 million was enough to rank in the top quartile.
The Vedder Price report noted that there were "due diligence issues associated with C.E.O. request to cash out," and acceleration of deferred and incentive compensation awards "is rare and inconsistent" with the "retention orientation of these programs."
Nonetheless, Vedder Price recommended that the board largely agree to what Mr. Grasso was asking. The only exception was that it recommended he not be allowed to cash in a $5 million bonus that was awarded in early 2001 but was to vest fully in 2006. That bonus was part of the money that Mr. Grasso ended up forfeiting.
The minutes of the meeting at which that bonus was awarded show that the board agreed that the $5 million should be awarded "for the outstanding contributions of Chairman Grasso" and that a similar payment should be made in future years. No discussion of the total amount of Mr. Grasso's pay, or how it compared with that of other financial services executives, is reflected in the minutes.
In fact, a $5 million bonus was awarded a year later, and was part of the money that Mr. Grasso was able to cash out last month. But no similar bonus was awarded early this year, and Mr. Grasso's total compensation for 2002 was cut to $12 million from more than $30 million the previous year.
