HEADLINE: U.S. Says Some 9/11 Aid for Downtown Businesses Went to Swindlers 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
Federal authorities in Manhattan are prosecuting at least a half-dozen cases in which people are charged with swindling nearly $600,000 from government programs intended to help Lower Manhattan businesses recover losses from 9/11 and to encourage residency in the area.
 At least a half-dozen more cases, involving $300,000 suspected of having been fraudulently sought or received, have been referred to federal investigators by a state agency administering one program. 
 The grant and loan programs involved have distributed more than $1 billion to businesses and residents in the aftermath of the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, 2001, which destroyed the World Trade Center and sent Lower Manhattan into an economic tailspin.
Suspected fraud totaling less than $1 million would seem to be small in the overall picture.But officials of the federal and state agencies involved said they had audited only a portion of the money distributed, making it very likely that more suspect grants and loans would turn up. 
"We consider the fraud rate small, but we do take it seriously, and it's not like it's going to be overlooked," said Alex Dudley, a spokesman for the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that administers the federally financed World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program. It has given nearly $540 million to more than 14,000 Lower Manhattan businesses to compensate them for economic losses attributed to 9/11.
Empire State referred the half-dozen or more suspicious cases involving $300,000 to federal investigators, Mr. Dudley said.
The two largest cases already being prosecuted by the United States attorney's office in Manhattan involve, wholly or in part, money awarded under the Business Recovery Grant Program.
In the biggest, two men, Alexander D. Koltovskoy and Vincent M. Pizzi III, are scheduled to stand trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Sept. 22 on charges that they fraudulently obtained $315,000 in grants and loans from the government, including nearly $65,000 in business recovery grants and a $228,000 disaster loan from the federal Small Business Administration.
They are accused of falsely claiming that their executive search company, Alexander Edwards International, was in 2 World Trade Center, the south tower, on Sept. 11, 2001, though prosecutors say it left the trade center in 1999.
The indictment charges that they buttressed their applications with fraudulent documents attesting to their presence in 2 World Trade Center on 9/11 and to having lost $87,000 in equipment, furniture and fixtures when the building collapsed.
Irving Anolik, Mr. Koltovskoy's lawyer, said Friday that his client was the company's president. He said that Mr. Koltovskoy "says he did not willingly or knowingly say anything false in his applications." He added that Mr. Koltovskoy "says that in many instances he was misled" by "contradictory and conflicting information" from officials when he applied to the programs.
A lawyer for Mr. Pizzi did not return a phone call to his office. Mr. Anolik said Mr. Pizzi was the company's manager.
In the second-biggest case, a Maryland resident, David Zimmer, is scheduled to be arraigned Wednesday on charges that he stole $270,000 from the Business Recovery Grant Program by claiming that a financial company he headed, DZ Investments, was in Suite 1023 at 40 Rector Street. That is several blocks south of the trade center, but close enough to qualify for the highest level of compensation.
Federal prosecutors said there was no Suite 1023 at 40 Rector. In fact, they said, the entire 10th floor of 40 Rector has been occupied by the New York City Commission on Human Rights for more than 10 years.
Mr. Zimmer, according to the charges, submitted to the Empire State Development Corporation what was "purported to be" a copy of his company's 2000 tax return, listing its address at 40 Rector and reporting more than $3 million in gross receipts. Grants were made based in part on a company's revenues during its last pre-9/11 tax year.
But the criminal complaint said that the company's 2000 tax return on file with the Internal Revenue Service listed its address at a home in Bethesda, Md., and reported zero gross receipts for the year. Mr. Zimmer is also accused of submitting a fake lease showing his company's occupancy at 40 Rector beginning in June 1995.
Mr. Zimmer did not respond to a message left Friday at a phone number, listed in his name, at the Bethesda address.
A spokesman for the Manhattan prosecutors would not say whether tips from the public, suspicions raised by program auditors or other signals had led investigators to focus on DZ Investments and Alexander Edwards International, nor would a spokesman for the office of the inspector general for the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which provided the money for the business recovery grants. 
The inspector general's office is under a Congressional directive to audit the department's 9/11-related spending closely.
The other federal court cases each involve several thousands of dollars reportedly swindled from a program under which the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation is using federal money to provide grants of up to $14,500 to encourage residents of Lower Manhattan to remain and others to move there. One case has resulted in a guilty plea; the others are pending.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT; 
For Serious Food in Sayville

BYLINE:  By JOANNE STARKEY; E-mail: lidining@nytimes.com

 BODY:
CRAZY DOG has put a bit of snap into the Sayville dining scene. The newcomer is the sibling of the seven-year-old Crazy Dog in Westhampton Beach, and like its big brother, the Sayville restaurant combines a whimsical air and decor with serious food.
 The sprawling, completely renovated building, which was last home to the J.D. Greenery bar and restaurant, offers a variety of seating. There are a half-dozen outdoor tables on the narrow front porch; a couple of tables in the action-filled barroom; a large, modern dining room with dark wood floors, wainscoting and natural-colored fabric on its walls; and an enclosed porch with two walls of large windows. Every table is graced with a white cloth, an ultramodern oil lamp and a spray of orchids. 
 The dog theme runs through the restaurant. A few statues of silly-looking canines are stationed near the entrance and on the bar. Another is perched above the hostess's station. In what seems to be a detail meant to complement the theme, the restrooms are labeled "sires" and "dames" (it could be worse).
 The beautiful barroom is an agreeable place for a drink. Apart from its crazed dog sculptures, it features dark blue walls, a marble bar, a bowl of orchids, a huge round wall mirror and seven tiny hanging lights, each with a purple or blue beaded shade.
 One potential drawback to the restaurant is its noise level. When the place fills up, conversation is difficult. And as much as I love 60's rock, it is not the ideal background music for a meal.
 Noise aside, there's plenty to like here. Service is sweet, caring and attentive, and the food is usually right on target.
 The executive chef is Eric Rifkin, an owner of the restaurants who has a head-turning resume. It includes a stint working with Anne Rosenzweig at the Lobster Club in Manhattan. That first-class experience is reflected in Mr. Rifkin's food, most apparently in the lobster club sandwich, a satisfying triple-decker with big chunks of lobster replacing the more familiar turkey. (That sandwich is also a star at the Crazy Dog in Westhampton Beach.)
 Mr. Rifkin is joined by John Holmes, his chef de cuisine. Long Islanders may remember him as the first chef at Tellers Chophouse in Islip. His experience there is reflected in the large lineup of steaks and chops at the Sayville Crazy Dog.
 Unfortunately, one of the two dishes that failed to measure up was one of those steaks: a very gristly, chewy rib-eye. The 12-ounce filet mignon, on the other hand, was butter-tender and exceptionally flavorful. It was made even better by the onion rings we ordered a la carte: a big platter of crisp wisps. At $4, they would make an economical appetizer for a table to share.
 The other shortfall was the Tuscan pizza, which had savory toppings -- prosciutto, mozzarella, tomato, arugula and truffle oil -- but also a too-thick, bready crust.
 Those two losers aside, nearly everything else was off the charts. The top three openers were the chopped salad loaded with assertive ingredients like calamata olives and oven-dried tomatoes; six crunchy fried oysters sitting on a bed of cooling diced cucumber and drizzled with a spicy chipotle aioli; and a seafood special that really impressed: a super-large four-ounce scallop placed over diced sweet potato, asparagus and corn in a scallop shell.
 Rounding out the seven sensational entrees (including the lobster club sandwich and the filet mignon) were three specials and two other choices from the menu. The two from the menu were a caramelized swordfish chop, served with tiny Manila clams, and tender pork osso bucco in a tangy barbecue sauce.
 The three specials were a beautifully cooked wild salmon; giant prawns, served with the heads still on and accompanied by diced tomatoes, pesto, a saffron aioli and broccolini; and a fall-away-tender lamb shank in a chipotle barbecue sauce. The last was crowned with onion rings and paired with both whipped and grilled sweet potatoes.
 We ignored the cheesecakes, which were made elsewhere, and zeroed in on the homemade desserts. The warm peach crisp made from local peaches and gilded with both ice cream and whipped cream was a hit, as were the same homemade doughnuts that wowed me at the Westhampton Beach Crazy Dog. The doughnuts, five sugar-coated, airy pillows with no center holes, arrived with a ramekin of warm raspberry dipping sauce. Two other must-orders were the fallen chocolate souffle with its gooey, rich texture and the very creamy rice pudding enhanced by a dollop of whipped cream.

HEADLINE: The Old South Fork, Not to Be Forgotten 

BYLINE:  By PETER C. BELLER

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON 

 BODY:
WHO remembers the best way to cook bunker, skirt Prohibition or hunt "coots" on Gardiners Bay? The old-timers of the South Fork remember, and after six years and almost 180 interviews their tales of fishing, farming and family life in East Hampton can now be read, listened to and watched.
 Comprising hundreds of pages of recollections and stories from the area's older residents, an oral history of East Hampton was completed and delivered to the town library's Pennypacker Long Island Collection in June. The project, begun in 1997 by Tony Prohaska and his partner, Martha Kalser, sought to capture memories of the South Fork on paper, audio and video tape before a generation of history is lost forever. 
 "People don't know there was a town there before the Hamptons was invented," said Mr. Prohaska, speaking of the decline of an older way of life as summer residents flooded into the area in the past 50 years. 
 Mr. Prohaska, 60, and Ms. Kalser, 65, set up a nonprofit organization and began interviewing friends and relatives. Even after they moved from East Hampton to Delray Beach, Fla., several years ago they continued their work, interviewing other former East Hamptonites who had to retired to the Sunshine State.
 The result, the History Project, is a fully indexed and transcribed series of interviews, some lasting several hours, covering the first half of the 20th century, a period framed roughly by the arrival of the railroad to the South Fork in 1895 and World War II. Photographs, memorabilia and original documents accompany many transcripts.
 "I had an idea of the kind of people I wanted to interview," said Mr. Prohaska, who felt he had to hurry because old age was fast claiming friends who were important sources of information. "I knew I wasn't going to get everybody."
 Each person who was interviewed suggested others who could provide more information on particular subjects, Ms. Kalser said. "Then the list began to grow," she said. "We just had to stop at one point."
 The interviews read like friendly conversations and range through dozens of topics, usually in just a few pages, with frequent references to forgotten place names and long-shuttered businesses and gathering spots.
 Three subjects appear frequently in the interviews: rum-running during Prohibition, the Hurricane of 1938 and World War II, the end of which saw the acceleration of the Hamptons' transition to a summer resort. First-hand accounts of the landing of Nazi saboteurs on an Amagansett beach in 1942 recount a brief time when the region caught the national spotlight.
 But it is reflections on aspects of an everyday life, now all but extinct, that give a real sense of the past.
 Abigail Edwards Field, now 105 years old, describes in one interview the deaths of her husband and two brothers while fishing in the 1938 storm, and in another conversation fondly recalls cooking bunker, now used as a baitfish. 
"Don't fry it because it's so full of the finest little rib bones," she said of the small, oily fish. Instead, her brother Sam would "put them in a dripping pan about so deep and a little water and a tiny bit of vinegar and let them go in the oven very, very slow. Then you could eat that fish and have a grand old time."
 While researching a possible book, Mr. Prohaska interviewed two dozen old-timers before deciding on the oral history project in 1997. One of the earlier interviews, in 1991, was with the late Mary Gosman, whose chowder shack on Montauk Harbor grew into the restaurant complex and wholesale fish market that is one of Montauk's highest-profile enterprises. She lamented the cost of modern medicine.
 "When somebody has a new baby that it's gonna cost $3,000 or more," said Mrs. Gosman, a mother of six. "Dr. Nugent delivered all of mine in my own house in Amagansett, $50 for each one. I've had no trouble whatever."
While the project's organizers intentionally avoided stories about the famous writers, artists and film stars who migrated to the East End, some of their interview subjects are known west of the Shinnecock Canal.
 Perry B. Duryea Jr., the former State Assembly speaker and onetime gubernatorial candidate, spoke about commercial fishing, hunting coots, as black ducks are sometimes known, and driving from Amagansett to Montauk on the "old cinder road," a stretch of Route 27 that was still unpaved.
 "When you put all these pieces together, it really is like a jigsaw puzzle," said Peter Garnham of the Amagansett Historical Society, an adviser on the project. "What happened at this baseball game? Do you remember the time the such and such house was moved? These are the things that don't make the newspapers but are the fabric of local history." 
 The audio recordings will preserve the local Bonac dialect, which harks back to the days when East Hampton was closer in travel time and spirit to New England than to New York City, Mr. Garnham said. The project is the first comprehensive oral history in the area and narrates East Hampton's evolution from a New England outpost to a fishing, whaling and farming center to a service-based economy.
 "We just put it out there," said Ms. Kalser, asked if the interviews perpetuate an overly rosy view of the past. "We didn't go in with an agenda. We had rich people. We had middle-class people, farmers and fishermen, politicians, teachers."
 Carleton Kelsey, a former Amagansett librarian and local historian who was interviewed for the project, said the casual style of interviewing elicits more honesty, not less, because people feel comfortable talking about things they might once have been embarrassed to speak of.
 "The people who were interviewed didn't hold anything back," Mr. Kelsey, 88, said.
 Mr. Prohaska said few people declined his requests to speak to them, although one man asked that parts of his testimony not be published until his death, fearing the frowns of his neighbors.
 Mr. Prohaska and Ms. Kalser are now working with Suffolk County Community College in Riverhead to transfer all the material to a single compact disc, which could be cheaply reproduced and distributed to other libraries and institutions.
 For some older residents, the oral history was a chance to feel that their lives were important and not forgotten.
 "They all seemed to have a life story they were waiting to tell," Mr. Prohaska said. "In a way, we were looking for the people that had that desire but nobody was going to ask them."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Two Neighbors Find Common Destination

BYLINE:  By WENDY GINSBERG

DATELINE: GLASSBORO 

 BODY:
ROWAN UNIVERSITY and the borough it has called home since about 1917 -- a mix of peach orchards and big-box stores and a faded downtown -- have been on speaking terms for several years. Now comes the tricky part: profiting from the conversation.
 "Twenty to 30 years ago this was a college town, and the college community came into the downtown," Joseph Brigandi Jr., the borough administrator, said recently. "But then there weren't strip malls and shopping malls nearby. The focus went away from downtown and it got run down." 
 But a failing downtown does not bode well for a university hoping to attract new students, especially since most high school seniors here graduate and then head to college in Pennsylvania. So this 9.2-square-mile town in the shadows of Camden and Philadelphia and the university decided they had to do something drastic -- cooperate-- if either was to survive. 
 "There's no question that we annoy each other," said Dr. Donald J. Farish, president of Rowan and a member of a steering committee that is trying to turn the town around. "It's a family that has to live together and is at times dysfunctional, but we keep our minds on the big picture."
 That picture paints Glassboro and its struggling downtown as a bustling college town, says Dr. Farish, on the order of Nassau Street in Princeton or George Street in New Brunswick. 
 That will be no easy task for this town of about 20,000 that derives its name from its past. As home to Stanger Glassworks and later the Whitney Brothers Glassworks, Glassboro was known as one of the state's top glass manufacturing towns from the late 18th century until 1920. But in 1917, when the glass business here was dying, residents donated land to the state in an effort to entice lawmakers to build a college. Eventually, Glassboro State College was born. 
 Few would even be aware of the existence of the college until 1967, when President Lyndon B. Johnson invited the Soviet premier, Aleksei Kosygin, to a summit here. Once again, the school would drop off most people's radar screens until 1992, when Henry Rowan, a local manufacturer who did not even attend Glassboro, donated $100 million -- at the time the largest sum ever given to a public university -- on the condition that the school be renamed after them. 
 Today, Rowan's collection of 42 buildings, sprawled across 25 acres, hugs the east side of the borough. About a half-mile from the university, a cluster of small shops that flank Glassboro's two main streets compose the downtown area.
 "Students come in here for tours and ask, 'Where are the coffee shops and book stores?"' said Dr. Farish. "I try to distract them and say, 'Hey, look over there cows!"' 
 During the summer, a retired professor at Rowan opened the town's first used book store, which also serves coffee. And while Dr. Farish is pushing for more stores to open downtown, Mr. Brigandi wants to make sure that Glassboro does not end up like neighboring Washington Township, which has a number of large chain stores. What neither man wants is for students to spend their money there or the nearby Deptford Mall.
 "Sometimes, you have a student body that comes primarily from suburbia," said Dr. James J. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. "It's a culture of regional malls and automobiles. You have to change their habits, and it doesn't happen by itself. There has to be something in that downtown for them to go to."
 Besides helping the town attract trendy shops visited by middle-class students with money to spend, the university also wants to nearly triple in size. But that kind of development takes tax dollars away from the borough and causes local homeowners to pay higher property taxes, since according to state law, colleges and universities are not required to pay taxes on land they own.
 "It's a double-edged sword that the presence of the university brings," Dr. Farish said. "It has an important and positive impact, but it also takes away taxes from the town."
 While Mr. Briganti estimated that more than $1 million a a year is lost in property taxes because of Rowan's presence, that is only part of the equation. Rowan brings an estimated $47 million a year to the borough, including $18.1 million in salaries for local residents and $25 million in revenue from students and visitors.
 "There's increasing employment because they're here," Mr. Briganti said. "And there's funding to build a technology park. And while they might not be paying a lot of taxes, they might cause other tax-paying businesses to come into town."
 Dr. Hughes also pointed out that if the university did not exist, many of Rowan's 25 acres would be covered instead with residential homes filled with children, who would each have to be educated at $10,000 a year, and that usually means higher property taxes.
 To offset the loss of property tax income and to maintain civil relations with the town, Rowan gives the borough $58,000 a year. "It's something by way of being a good neighbor," said Dr. Farish. "Rubbing people's nose in things doesn't make it better."
 Dr. Farish's neighborliness is about to be tested again. As recently as last Wednesday, Dr. Farish postponed a vote to authorize negotiations with a modular townhouse manufacturer after residents urged the university not to clear an area off Route 322 tract for student housing -- part of a $27.3 million project -- in one of the borough's oldest wooded tracts.
 Relations between the university and borough were not always so amicable. Just five years ago, before Dr. Farish took over as president, most here agree that there was no cooperation between the two entities. "It wasn't that there was a dislike or anything, but neither side was working together," Mr. Brigandi said. "Anything that happened off campus wasn't their problem."
 Today, university officials are encouraging students and faculty members to become active in the community. To that end, for three years the university has offered an an incentive -- an additional $1,500 a year for 10 years -- to get faculty members to move here.
 Courtney Richmond and Michael Grove, biology professors who are married, were among the first to move in.
 "It wasn't just the money," said Ms. Richmond. "It's great to be able to walk to work. We do experiments all the time and this gives us the ability to walk there because we're right near campus. And a lot of other faculty are moving into this area. It's really positively affecting our social lives."
 But the timing of the initiative was unfortunate. Not long after Rowan bought 17 acres here for a new presidential house and meeting center, the costly plans were tabled. Instead, the university bought a sprawling granite house in nearby Woodbury for $685,000 and then made another $300,000 in renovations.
 Nonetheless, Glassboro officials want to make the most of the rapprochement with the university, and have promised nearly $12 million in improvements, including the construction of a road that would link the university to the downtown. As it is now, students have to weave through a cluster of residential streets to get to the small downtown strip. In addition, borough officials would like to build a hotel with conference rooms adjacent to the university, though the move is opposed by some residents because it would mean the demolition of existing homes, including Betty Morro's 55-year-old house.
 "I'm upset," said Ms. Morro, a 70-year-old widow who lives in the path of the planned thoroughfare. "I don't want to leave my house. My husband built this house. I plan to die here. Where would I go?"
 Across the street, Anthony and DeAnna Kennedy, who are both disabled, are not particularly eager for the new road to be built. "We appreciate the university," said the 49-year-old Mr. Kennedy. "I even went there when it was Glassboro State. But I love this house. We'll be able to go somewhere, I guess, but we don't want to go anywhere."
 Rowan's nascent expansion has also met with some resistance in Camden, where the university wants to take over an entire block to build a $10-million, five-story building.
 That block thrived through the 1970's, when it was primarily home to a cluster of law and insurance offices as well as some small retail businesses. It fell into disrepair in the 1980's, but over the last decade, shops and restaurants have moved in, catering primarily to the expanding Rutgers-Camden campus nearby. Moreover, some of the buildings on the block are historically significant, including an ornate old bank building at North Third and Market Streets.
 Despite the hurdles that face both Rowan and Glassboro, Dr. Hughes of Rutgers says both are on the right path. 
 "Improvements to the community really make the school better," said Dr. Hughes, noting the success that Rutgers has had in New Brunswick and the University of Pennsylvania's efforts to improve its surroundings in West Philadelphia. "You've really got to work hard."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Hey, What Happened to My Rebate?

BYLINE:  By JON SHURE; Jon Shure is president of New Jersey Policy Perspective, which conducts research on state issues.

 BODY:
NOW -- perhaps still sitting in a mailbox near you -- the incredible shrinking rebate.
 Yes it's that time of year again. The State of New Jersey is sending checks to homeowners as its way of saying, "We know your property taxes are too high, so here's a little something." 
 And this year it's a "littler" something than before. That's because even though the State of New Jersey cares about you very much, well, to tell you the truth it's a bit short these days. You know, bad economy, budget crisis and all that. 
 Last year Governor McGreevey helped to close the state budget gap by trimming people whose yearly income surpassed $200,000 from the list of who would receive NJ Saver rebate checks. This year he proposed limiting the checks to those making $100,000 or more, but the Legislature balked. Better to cut the rebate checks in half, lawmakers said, than to cut anyone else off the list. So this year the average check is $250 instead of $500. The Legislature also passed a budget that virtually froze aid to schools and municipalities -- assuring that most people's property tax bills will go up this year by much more than the $250.
 O.K., $250 is nothing to sneeze at. Who couldn't use a few extra bucks?
 But sooner or later, someone is going to convince the people of New Jersey there is a better way. This rebate business like putting a Band-Aid on cancer. It all started in 1976, when New Jersey first imposed a state income tax. We came to it later than most states, and figured that one way to ease the sting would be to make very sure the tax could be used for only one purpose: reducing the burden of local property taxes.
 So far, so good, because no state relies more than New Jersey on property taxes, and this causes big problems. It means some towns can afford better schools and services than other towns because they have abundant property wealth to tax. It also means that elderly residents who bought their houses for a song 50 years ago and long ago paid off their mortgage are now getting clobbered by a tax bill based on the hugely escalated value of their house rather than on their income -- the latter being a far more reliable measure of someone's ability to pay.
 If the state's impulse was well placed, the execution leaves a bit to be desired. Property tax relief means school aid and municipal aid, and the state provides these things. But the decision was also made in '76 that a piece of the property tax pie ought to be handed directly to homeowners (renters too, by use of a formula that calculates approximately what percentage of their rent goes to pay the landlord's property tax bill). The vehicle back then was the Homestead Rebate. And the fact that the first checks went our shortly before Election Day in 1977 was no coincidence. Gov. Brendan T. Byrne was running for re-election and a lot of people thought his presiding over the passage of the income tax would make him a goner.
 Mr. Byrne won in a landslide, and the rebate check became a New Jersey staple. The Homestead Rebate went through various changes over the years, and in the 1990's, Gov. Christie Whitman created NJ Saver to be the largest of four programs that put property tax relief directly into people's hands. It was a very generous plan, based on the value of your house and what share of your tax bill went for school financing (the statewide average being about half).
 In fact, it was too generous. Since the money wasn't there to implement the program in full, Governor Whitman decided to phase it in over five years. She said the state would handle the increased costs through expanded revenue from the growing economy and from continued government efficiency. Then the economy pretty much stopped growing. And while one shouldn't go so far as to say "government efficiency" is an oxymoron, we're talking about a couple billion dollars needed for tax relief here.
 Today, Governor McGreevey maintains the tax rebate tradition, if in a reduced version. What he should do instead is scrap it completely. This patchwork system of adding a program here and there doesn't give enough relief and doesn't deliver it to those most in need. Better to end the charade. Raise broad state taxes based on people's ability to pay -- like the income tax -- and use the money to pay for more of the services that towns and schools today pay from property taxes. It's time to stop nibbling at the edges. The problem is too big for that. And it's only getting bigger -- even as the rebates grow smaller.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Drawing by Tom Bloom)

HEADLINE: Proposal at W.T.O. Meeting Rejects Changes in Subsidies 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER and GINGER THOMPSON

DATELINE: CANCUN, Mexico, Sept. 13 

 BODY:
A compromise proposal issued at the meeting of the World Trade Organization here today rejects most of the pleas for change in agriculture from the developing world, including African cotton producers, and generally allows the United States to maintain its billions in annual subsidies.
 The proposal, which had been prepared to help narrow the differences that have stalled progress on a global trade agreement, was met with disappointment by several of the developing nations that formed the so-called Group of 21 to stand together against the world's economic heavyweights, the United States, Europe and Japan. 
 Celso Amorim, the Brazilian minister of foreign affairs, said in an interview that the compromise draft offered "much less than we would expect."
"The changes for us are very modest, but if not for the G-21 we would have gotten nothing," he added. 
Nevertheless, Mr. Amorim said the coalition of developing nations would not be divided by the setback.
"We are alive and fighting," he said, "not in a confrontational way but with dialogue."
Under the proposal, Europe would begin eliminating export subsidies for agricultural goods. In exchange, the W.T.O. would broaden categories covered by trade rules, to include investment. Developing countries do not want the rules expanded in such a fashion, for fear that the trade laws will undermine their national laws covering labor, human rights and environmental protection. Environmental groups say the proposal could erode current environmental protections in favor of foreign investment. Negotiators have until Sunday night to amend the proposal, and then accept or reject it.
This round of trade talks, begun two years ago in Qatar, was called to help developing countries and was expected to produce a big reduction in the $300 billion paid every year to farmers in the world's richest nations. Those subsidies, which have undermined the lives of millions of farmers in the world's poorest nations, have been deemed unfair by the World Bank.
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said in a short statement that he found the new proposal "constructive."
The proposal offered a reprieve to American cotton farmers, some of the most heavily subsidized in the world. And it urged beleaguered African farmers to plant other crops. There is no mention of paying compensation for the losses to the farmers, as requested.
Chanting "Down Down W.T.O.," some 2,000 protesters tore down fortified barricades today that had been erected by the police to keep demonstrators away from the talks. Some protesters rolled a battering ram cobbled from garbage cans and a tree trunk, vowing to "tear down the barriers of imperialism."
Dozens of women carrying wire cutters began slicing holes into the tall chain-link security fence. Meanwhile other protesters, led by a group of South Korean activists, tied rope to the frame and pulled the fence to the pavement.
Police officers made minimal effort to stop the protest. And after accomplishing their goal, W.T.O. opponents from at least 20 countries, many of them students, sat in the street and applauded their solidarity. There were no clashes between the protesters and the police.
Globalization opponents said the demonstration was the climax of a week of action intended to draw attention to the people and places they say have been harmed by existing free-trade treaties and unfettered foreign investment. Parallel to the trade organization's meeting, nonprofit organizations from around the world have held forums to present alternative economic development strategies that they say would put poor countries on a more level playing field with the United States, Europe and Japan.
Protests -- some playful and others deadly serious -- have tried to dramatize the plight of millions of small farmers who cannot compete with subsidized products from the United States and Europe that flood world markets. Demonstrators threw corn on speakers at news briefings by the United States and took off swimsuits to spell out "No W.T.O." with their bodies in the sand.
On Wednesday, a march by several thousand farmers turned violent when a few dozen protesters broke through barricades and lobbed sticks and pieces of concrete at police. In the heat of the fighting, a South Korean farmer, wearing a sign that said "W.T.O. Kills Farmers," climbed to the top of a barricade and fatally stabbed himself. "Sometimes violence is the only choice of the poor or the weak," said Kim Seok, a South Korean demonstrator.
Newspapers here ran almost daily warnings of terror by the protesters. Authorities transformed this resort into a bunker, with thousands of federal police manning roadblocks and navy ships floating off the coast.
But the protests in Cancun have not escalated to the violence that marred the WTO meetings in Seattle in 1999. Protesters acknowledged that their attitudes had been tempered by international terrorism and their opposition to the war against Iraq. Still, they said, their commitment to the cause remained strong.
"We believe that people on an international level are gaining a real conscience of the problems of agriculture," said Rafael Alegria, the leader of an international farmers' organization called Via Campesina. "We feel that the people are supporting us in our just demands."

HEADLINE: Pregnant Workers Filing More Complaints of Bias 

BYLINE:  By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU

 BODY:
WITH the economy uncertain and many companies looking to keep down costs and pare their employment rolls, growing numbers of workers are filing charges of pregnancy discrimination. 
 Lawyers specializing in labor law as well as leaders of women's advocacy groups around the country say they have detected an increase in pregnancy discrimination cases in recent years. And at the federal level, claims of discriminatory treatment during pregnancy filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have increased 39 percent over the last 10 years, to 4,714 in 2002. That is a tiny fraction of the number of working women, but Jocelyn C. Frye, director of legal and public policy for the National Partnership for Women and Families, a nonprofit advocacy group for women in the workplace, said that this was because pregnancy discrimination cases rarely reach the federal level. Many complaints are handled by state agencies, settled or simply dropped. 
 "Most women are not inclined to go to court, especially with a baby coming," she said. Even so, the number of women calling her organization for information on how to handle discrimination has increased over the last two years, she said. 
Ellen Bravo, the director of 9to5 National Association of Working Women in Milwaukee, said, "Pregnancy discrimination is still alive and well and escalating." She attributed some of the increase in complaints to corporate downsizing, but said a heightened awareness of women's rights at work also played a role. 
Jennifer James, 24, says she believes she was a victim of pregnancy discrimination when she lost her job at a brewery-style restaurant in Lake Grove on Long Island.
According to a suit being brought on her behalf in United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York by the equal-employment commission, Ms. James was promoted from server to supervisor at the restaurant, one of a chain owned by John Harvard's Brew House, which is based in Braintree, Mass.
But Ms. James said that things fell apart in April 2001, after she told her manager that she was pregnant. "He asked me, 'Are you sure about this?' and 'Have you considered your options?"' she said in a recent interview.
In the weeks that followed her disclosure, she said, she found herself taken off the schedule and unable to get work at any John Harvard restaurants. According to the commission's complaint, the company misbehaved by "denying her any work assignments despite her repeated requests and terminating her employment in approximately August 2001."
John Harvard's president, Michael Hackney, declined to discuss details of the case other than to say that Ms. James's pregnancy had nothing to do with what happened to her. He said his firm was the "model of diversity" with 40 percent of its general managers being women. 
Deborah Weinstein, a labor and employment lawyer in Philadelphia who also teaches employment law at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, said the increasing number of pregnancy cases can be traced to more women working, and a greater awareness of workers' rights. The introduction of the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, she said, has also led more pregnant women to assert their rights under the law.
At the same time, the weak economy is forcing companies to cut back, inevitably laying off some pregnant women or women on maternity leave when they let groups of employees go, legal experts said. 
Pressure to improve performance and profitability has led some managers to panic when they hear that a crucial employee is pregnant, said Mark S. Spring, a lawyer in Sacramento with Carlton, DiSante & Freudenberger, who represents employers in labor disputes.
Mr. Spring also recalled a case in which he represented a company where a manager was being pushed for better performance. "The regional sales manager was under pressure to increase the performance in his region, and as a result he shifted this pregnant woman onto a much smaller territory in his region before she went out on leave," he said. She sued, and the company ended up settling that case. 
Over the last two years, Mr. Spring said, he has seen a steep rise in the number of pregnancy discrimination cases at his firm, with three to four cases going on at any given time, compared with one such case every few years in the past.
Ms. Bravo of 9to5 says she believes that pregnancy discrimination cases are undercounted because many women are afraid to make waves. Some accept demotions because they are happy to have a job and others believe that a lawsuit could be career suicide. 
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is using the John Harvard case to shed light on what it believes is the growing problem of pregnancy discrimination, said Kam S. Wong, a trial lawyer for the commission.
But cases of pregnancy discrimination rarely reflect a companywide prejudice, said Charles Joseph, a lawyer in Manhattan with Joseph & Herzfeld who represents employees in labor disputes "It's usually idiot individuals within corporations."
Mr. Joseph generally advises employees who suspect discrimination to try to work things out with direct supervisors before lodging a formal complaint with human resources or upper management. 
It is also important for an employee to keep records if pregnancy discrimination is a concern, he said. 
The Pregnancy Discrimination Act of 1978 gives narrow entitlements to pregnant women, said Ms. Weinstein of Wharton. Employers are required to treat pregnant employees in the same manner they would treat nonpregnant employees with similar abilities or limitations.
They are not required to make special accommodations related to pregnancy because pregnancy is not a disability under the Americans With Disabilities Act. "You can be fired if you don't do your job," she said.
In several cases, the courts have ruled in favor of employers who fired pregnant women who were consistently late even though the women said they were experiencing morning sickness. While the Family and Medical Leave Act entitles women to take some time off from work to deal with severe morning sickness or prenatal examinations, they may not be protected if lateness affects their job performance and an employer reprimands or fires other nonpregnant employees for similar behavior.
Experts on women's employment emphasize that communication with managers about the issues surrounding pregnancy is critical. "Go to your boss, make recommendations," said Marcia Brumit Kropf, vice president for research and information services at Catalyst, a nonprofit research firm in New York focused on helping to women advance in business. "Tell them you'll train someone before you go out on leave, and assure him or her you won't disappear when you take time off after delivery."
But such assurances, Ms. Brumit Kropf said, "may not work for every manager in America."
Indeed, Ms. James, the former John Harvard supervisor, said she reassured her manager she would still be committed to her job and take only four weeks of maternity leave. "I wasn't expecting special treatment," she said. "I would have done anything to keep my job, the secure income, especially with the baby coming." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jennifer James with her daughter, Jaidyn. Ms. James says she lost her job because of pregnancy discrimination. (Photo by Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
The Philharmonic Struggles in Uncertain Times

BYLINE:  By BRIAN WISE

 BODY:
THE Long Island Philharmonic begins its 25th season on Friday, an anniversary that many orchestras would mark with special programming, commissioned works, tours or recordings. But the ensemble's board spent the summer trying to whittle away a $300,000 deficit and searching for a new executive director. Management and musicians alike hope that the performances of Dvorak's "New World" Symphony scheduled for the opening programs will be a celebration of the orchestra's own rebirth.
 "Dollar-wise we have been in worse shape in the past, but one of the main concerns now is the direction of the economy," said John Russell, president of the Philharmonic's board. "Whether or not we can expect corporations and government entities to return to their former levels of support, that's the concern." 
 The economic troubles, which last season included paying the musicians late, come in the midst of criticism by players about the group's artistic direction. Among the complaints are the steady reduction of the length of the subscription season and an increased reliance on popular fare, which some say comes at the expense of the creative programming that helped the Philharmonic attain a strong reputation as a regional orchestra under conductors like Christopher Keene, its founding music director, and Marin Alsop, music director from 1990 to 1996.
 Like many American orchestras, the Philharmonic saw its funding base decline after Sept. 11, 2001, accelerating financial problems it was already having because of the weak economy and forcing it to cut many educational programs.
 A move to shore up the orchestra's finances came in June 2002, when the board hired Chris Von Zwehl as its executive director. He is an entrepreneur who helped raise money for Empire Waterlink, a New Jersey company building a ferry service with New York, but has no musical background. When Mr. Von Zwehl resigned in May, the orchestra named Brian McCaffrey, a board member, to take over until a replacement is found.
 "The candidate has to know something about music, although I don't think that's the primary quality we're looking for," said Larry Austin, chairman of the Philharmonic's board and a member of the search committee. "The primary quality is executive leadership style, and number two is being able to manage the organization. But he's got to know the difference between Tchaikovsky and Billy Joel."
 While the orchestra has had brushes with bankruptcy before, the present problems appear to have descended quickly upon an unsuspecting board, largely because of cuts in state and local government assistance. The orchestra has traditionally received what Mr. McCaffrey called "a significant amount of money" from the state, but in recent years has seen less from that source.
 The present deficit of $300,000 affects an annual budget of $2.1 million, which pays for hall rentals, marketing and production costs, as well as paying the musicians and David Wiley, the music director.
 Ticket and subscription sales account for 19 percent of the orchestra's revenue, foundation grants account for 3 percent, gifts 6 percent, sponsorships 17 percent, and fundraising, which includes the orchestra's annual gala concert, 35 percent. State and local governments contribute 15 percent. The Philharmonic does not have an endowment.
 Mr. McCaffrey said the orchestra was appealing to corporations, private donors and foundations for money. So far, it has not asked for pay cuts in musicians' salaries, which are 32 percent of its annual budget. New contract negotiations with the players are scheduled to begin next year.
 Last season, the orchestra had to scramble to pay the musicians for the final concerts. Eventually, the union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, was instrumental in getting the players paid.
 Among musicians, there is criticism of the programming under Mr. Wiley, who was appointed in 2001. This season, for example, the "Classics" series, traditionally devoted to core orchestral literature, includes one program consisting of film scores as well as others with familiar, light fare like Grieg's "Peer Gynt" Suite. 
 "Finding a balance between pops and classics is an age-old question," Mr. Wiley said. "But we don't sacrifice classics to do more pops." He added: "After 9/11, we did not remove any of the classics programs. The board, staff and I thought that it was essential to our identity and to the quality of the group."
 Mr. McCaffrey, acting executive director, said the orchestra was trying "to offer a little bit wider range of programming." He continued: "There are people who clearly will go to a pops concert that will also go to a classical one. This is an active discussion with this board all of the time. How do we shift with the times? What do the listeners want to hear? How do we maintain our mission and provide a broader range? What you see now is that evolution. I don't think it's dominated by pops, but it has that element."
 The Philharmonic was founded by the late folk singer Harry Chapin and C.R. Merolla, president of the Bank of Babylon, who met in 1978 to unite two struggling local orchestras, the Long Island Symphony and the Suffolk Symphony. By the mid-80's, the Philharmonic was featured on several recordings and a series of radio concerts on WQXR in New York. The orchestra has long engaged international-caliber soloists. 
 This season features only one major soloist, the cellist Lynn Harrell, who opens the season playing Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky. The rest of the programs cut costs by featuring local musicians, and several of the orchestra's own players as soloists. The unpaid Long Island Symphony Chorus has been engaged for two programs.
 Meanwhile, over the years, subscription concerts have been reduced. In the 1980's and early 90's, the orchestra presented as many as eight sets of programs a year, consisting of two or three concerts each. This brought together the musicians, two-thirds of whom commute from New York City, New Jersey and Westchester County, for at least one concert per month from September through May.
 This season there are five programs, consisting of two concerts each, plus a pops concert and a New Year's Eve celebration. Management points out that there are two more concerts this year than last.
 Mr. McCaffrey remains optimistic that new sponsors will be found to help the group become financially healthy. The Melville-based healthcare product distributor Henry Schein is sponsoring the November subscription concerts, he said, adding that other deals are in the works. The board is also in talks with several concert promoters about plans for a benefit fundraising concert at the Nassau Coliseum for November.
 "The notion would be to hopefully get some name artists, hopefully Long Islanders, to come and play and help us raise money," Mr. McCaffrey said.
 The Long Island Philharmonic will perform on Friday at 8 p.m. at Tilles Center in Brookville, and on Saturday at 8 p.m. at Staller Center in Stony Brook. Information: (631)293-2222 or www.liphilharmonic.com.

GRAPHIC: Photos: David Wiley, above and left, conducting the Long Island Philharmonic. The orchestra struggled financially last season. Its management and its players hope this year will be better. (Photographs by Bruce Bennett Studios)

HEADLINE: Blown Away 

BYLINE:  By TOM CLAVIN

 BODY:
WITHOUT weather satellites, and before radar had been introduced as a forecasting tool, the people of Long Island never saw the meteorological beast before it pounced on Sept. 21, 1938, 65 years ago next Sunday.
 A mighty hurricane roared in from the Atlantic. Sustained winds were 120 miles per hour as the storm's eye came ashore at Westhampton Beach. Fifty-one people died on the Island, which suffered about $365 million worth of damage, estimated in today's dollars. 
 In the days before such storms were given official names, the 1938 hurricane was dubbed the Long Island Express because it advanced at speeds of up to 60 m.p.h. and, after finishing with the Island, it hit five New England states in just six hours. It remains the most devastating weather event on Long Island, and with about 600 total deaths it was the fourth deadliest hurricane in United States history. In addition to those killed, 63,000 were left homeless, 8,900 buildings were destroyed, 3,300 boats were lost and two billion trees were destroyed. 
 Numerous signs of the storm's brutality remain on the East End. (Being on the west side of the storm, the rest of Suffolk County and Nassau sustained less damage.) The landmark Old Whalers Church in Sag Harbor has a curiously boxy, squat appearance, its huge steeple having been toppled in the storm and never replaced. The fishing village on the strip of land between Fort Pond Bay and Fort Pond was obliterated, never to be rebuilt. The most prominent reminders are the Shinnecock Inlet and the Shinnecock Canal, gouged out of the land by the storm and later dredged and lined and made hospitable for boat traffic.
 A person born the day of the '38 Storm would just be approaching the traditional retirement age today. But many who lived through it and were old enough to understand what was happening are still around, and their memories of the event tend to be vivid.
 Sherrill Foster, the East Hampton town historian, was a junior at East Hampton High School in the fall of 1938. Someone, she said, called the principal on Sept. 21 to tell him that a hurricane was approaching. "'We don't have hurricanes here,' he said, and slammed the phone down," Ms. Foster, 81, said recently in her home in East Hampton. "But when the kindergarteners were let out and they were being blown up against the chain-link fence, it was clear this was no ordinary storm.
 "We were told to go to our seats in the auditorium," she continued. "Most of the students, like my brother Edwin, just left and walked home. The Montauk kids were being put up in East Hampton because it was already too late to call out the buses. I sat in the auditorium, and the two gym teachers, male and female, came in with a record player. They put a record on and started dancing to reassure the students, but it was obvious they were scared to death." She was soon brought home in her father's milk truck.
 "It was a frightening day and night, and there was some damage to the farmhouse," Ms. Foster remembered. "The next day, a gorgeous one, my mother took my brother and me to Montauk. Napeague Stretch was under water. After we got through we went to the fishing village, where we had relatives and my mother had lived as a child. It was gone."
 The residents of the fishing village survived, and the oral history collection at the Montauk Library explains how. It includes a reminiscence by Gus Pitts, one of the port's first charter boat captains. Interviewed in 1994 -- he died last year at age 97 -- he recalled being on Lake Montauk that afternoon and seeing "the tidal wave coming over the jetty" and then "a puff of wind" blowing his father's car into the air, never to be found. His family and about 100 other residents of the village survived because they climbed aboard a Long Island Rail Road train on a track six feet higher than the beach and it took them west to higher ground.
 Ria Del Bene, an 83-year-old Westhampton Beach resident, remembers watching the water draining from Moniebogue Canal behind Main Street. "Not being knowledgeable about tidal waves, I didn't realize that the water gets sucked out, then comes back in a tidal wave," she recalled. She also watched as "the wind picked up a large wild cherry tree, at least 100 years old, pulled it up, roots and all, and then laid it on the ground like a huge bouquet."
 Richard Hendrickson, a Bridgehampton farmer who has been an official observer for the Weather Service for 73 years, said Long Island and Manhattan were actually lucky because of the speed of the storm. 
 "It was the fastest-moving hurricane ever recorded," said Mr. Hendrickson, who is 91. "If it had been slower, it would have flooded the South Fork and washed away half of both eastern forks. Then it would have flooded the Sound, raising water levels all the way to the city, flooding the lower half of Manhattan."
 In 1938, Mr. Hendrickson was raising breeding hens and selling the eggs from the thousands of chickens he owned. During the storm, two of his six henhouses were blown away. The chickens did not fare any better. "The wind blew the chicks against my six-foot-high fence and the rain drowned them," he recalled.
 With the hurricane far from being a distant memory, the questions 65 years later are: Could it happen again, and what have we learned?
 The answers are yes, and not much, said Michael Wyllie, the meteorologist in charge at the National Weather Service office in Upton. "We haven't seen anything like the 1938 storm, and maybe that has prompted some complacency," he said. "But if a strong Category 3 hurricane like that one hit today, it would be the biggest natural disaster the country has seen, period. We have built up the coast of southern Long Island pretty much with abandon. We just did whatever we wanted to do. There really hasn't been much in the way of regulation in those 65 years."
 During the last two decades there have been some big blows, especially Hurricane Gloria in 1985 and Bob in 1991. Mr. Wyllie pointed out, however, that both were Category 1, the weakest class of hurricane, and because the eye of Bob passed to the east of Montauk Point, the Island was spared the worst of the storm's winds.
 "The damage was a few billion dollars in 1938 because of the lower population and development," Mr. Wyllie said, adjusting for inflation and including damage beyond the Island. "Estimates are, if we got hit with that same storm today, we're looking at a $75 billion loss." The record for storm damage is held by Hurricane Andrew, which wreaked an inflation-adjusted $20 billion worth of havoc on South Florida in 1992.
 The $75 billion estimate was echoed by AIR Worldwide Corporation in Boston, a risk-assessment company that recently completed a study on the impact of a storm similar to the one in 1938. Karen Clark, chief executive of the company, said that $40 billion of the estimated total damage would occur in Suffolk, Nassau, Queens and Brooklyn.
 "The biggest influence on that figure is if a storm were to hit Long Island at high tide like the one in '38 did," Ms. Clark said. "A lot of the damage would be caused by the storm surge."
 Stephen Leatherman, director of the International Hurricane Research Center at Florida International University in Miami and a consultant at Southampton College of Long Island University, has predicted that a "killer hurricane" will ravage the South Shore of Long Island in the next 15 to 20 years. 
 "There's even more vulnerability now than in 1938," said Dr. Leatherman, who recently completed a three-year laser-mapping of the shoreline from the Moriches Inlet to Montauk. "Since '38 the sea level on the South Shore of Long Island has crept up a half a foot or so, and beach recession has averaged 1.5 feet per year. This tells you the beaches and the dunes are more narrow, meaning less of a barrier against the storm surge. And of course the amount of building that has gone on is enormous. It's phenomenal. I've looked at some of the aerial photos from the '30s and compare them to what I see today, and you can hardly recognize it."
 Dr. Leatherman noted that Hurricane Fabian, which hammered Bermuda on Sept. 5, followed a track similar to that of the '38 Storm before turning northeast.
 "That's just one hurricane that gave us pause, so there is definitely a vulnerability," he said. "Looking at the historical data, there's roughly a 75-year frequency to these big ones. I think right now we're pretty close to the median time when you have to really worry. To think it won't happen is like expecting someone flipping a coin and getting 10 heads in a row."
 Yet this and similar warnings have mostly gone unheeded during six decades of real estate development, including a heavy buildup of South Shore bay- and oceanfront properties. When a mere northeaster in 1992 wrecked a stretch of the barrier beach west of Westhampton Beach, the homes there were not only rebuilt bigger and better, but its residents also incorporated a new village, West Hampton Dunes, to protect their right to rebuild oceanfront residences after storm damage. 
 A similar motivation underlies the effort now under way to incorporate the Village of Dune Hampton along the eastern coast of Southampton Town. The actor Roy Scheider has been the most visible proponent of Dune Hampton and an opponent of the town's recently enacted Coastal Erosion Hazard Law, which bans permanent shore-hardening structures and seeks to restrict oceanfront development.
 "Living at the beach is risky, and you pay high insurance prices for the privilege," Mr. Scheider said. "There are many of us here, we've been here a long time, and we accept the risk.
 "I know there are people who consider us damn fools and that you shouldn't live at the beach anyhow, but it's a free country and it's our choice," Mr. Scheider continued. "We paid the price to be here, and we'll pay the price to not be here. But it's our decision, and that should be respected."
 The attitude of waterfront owners can be vexing to lawmakers. "People love to live on the beach, and they are willing to live with the risk until the risk comes, and then they'd like you to bail them out," said Dennis Suskind, a Southampton town councilman. "That's human nature."
 The risk may be greater than some oceanfront homeowners realize. "Storm surge damage is excluded from a lot of insurance policies today," Ms. Clark said. "Someone who lives on the water, unless he has separate flood insurance their normal policy won't pay for surge damage."
 But Dr. Leatherman said it is tough to walk away from an oceanfront home. "It's just such high-value real estate," he said. "And let's face it, people have gotten away with it for a long time now, haven't they?"
 Say a hurricane mimics the 1938 storm and aims for Long Island. Is the region toast? While higher population and shoreline development might be the bad news, the good news is more sophisticated forecasting and stronger structures.
 "Today, with our satellites, we look at these things very closely," Mr. Wyllie said. "With Fabian, we were able to track its every move. We would have ample time to get people away. Question is, will they move?" 
 Move where? is the big question on the South Fork, which is notorious for the traffic jams along Route 27 on normal days, let alone emergency evacuations. "I find it interesting and humorous sometimes that we have coastal road evacuation signs when there's only one road off the South Fork," Mr. Suskind said.
 But Mr. Wyllie said that residents of the East End would not have to leave the area altogether to be safe. 
 "We've done a lot of work with Suffolk County emergency managers, and I'm pretty comfortable that they would be very proactive in getting word out and moving people," he said. "We're able to predict by combining various factors how high the wall of water will be on the shoreline when a hurricane makes landfall. Unfortunately, on Long Island it's really high, one of the highest in the country." He explained that Long Island, jutting out from the Eastern Seaboard, tends to trap and intensify the surge from any storm moving up the coast. 
 The laser-mapping project may well help in this regard too. "The maps we have are very much outdated, and we don't really know the flood zones very well," Dr. Leatherman said. "We can't pinpoint what areas of the Hamptons will be safer than others, other than, obviously, the higher ground, where you're more vulnerable to wind damage. People in waterfront and low-lying areas have to run from the storm surge, then see what's left the next day. From the Hamptons in general, there isn't a way out because it's just going to be panicked people sitting in motionless cars as two-by-fours are being tossed into their windows by the wind. But we can find the areas people will be best protected."
 Mr. Suskind said that because of stronger guidelines from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the building and rebuilding being done on the South Shore is much sturdier and storm-resistant than it was years ago. "As a homeowner here, you can't escape a hurricane," he said. "What you can do by following the FEMA regulations is increase the chance of withstanding a storm and decrease the risk of damage."
 Whatever the benefits of better forecasting, better-built structures and preparedness, a hurricane as powerful as the one in 1938 would have a highly destructive impact.
 Last September, the weekly Southampton Press published a three-part series of articles on the impact on the East End of a hypothetical Hurricane Emily following the same track as the 1938 storm. The articles were based on FEMA and National Hurricane Center scenarios of a Category 3 storm, not the strongest but probably the most powerful likely to make it this far north. By the time the fictional storm had moved on, fewer than 30 percent of the homes on the South Shore from Moriches Bay to Amagansett remained.
 With this possible scenario in mind, Mr. Wyllie has attended as many as 70 town meetings around Long Island to promote hurricane preparedness and the need for evacuation plans, and to counsel people to have realistic expectations.
 "We're certainly not ready for such a storm," Mr. Wyllie said. "But we can save lives; that's the top priority. Property damage? Forget about it, that's gone."

HEADLINE: UP FRONT: WORTH NOTING; 
The Big Screen Comes to Haddonfield

BYLINE:  By Robert Strauss

 BODY:
Hooray for Haddonfield.
 On Monday, this Victorian-style hamlet in Camden County will become the Hollywood of New Jersey as Governor McGreevey signs the New Jersey Film Production Assistance Program there. 
 After the 1 p.m. signing ceremony at Haddonfield Memorial High School, the actor Paul Sorvino and his production company will begin auditioning teenagers for a film he intends to shoot, at least partly in Haddonfield, entitled "Trouble with Callie." Other stars expected to attend the ceremony are William Baldwin, Michelle Lee and Chazz Palminteri.
 The film may be the first to take advantage of the new program, which is designed to give loan guarantees of up to $1.5 million to film projects that do at least 70 percent of their production and spend 50 percent of their expenses in New Jersey.
 Micah Rasmussen, the governor's spokesman, noted that the governor has promised to bring 200,000 new jobs to New Jersey, and that film and television production can become a big part of that. "Outside of California, the New York/New Jersey area has historically been a center for film production," Mr. Rasmussen said. "The more we can attract to New Jersey, the better it will be for the economy here." Robert Strauss
